			class="vector-toc-list-item vector-toc-level-2">
			<a class="vector-toc-link" href="#Election_interference">

					<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading mw-first-heading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">2024 United States presidential election</span></h1>
							
<div id="p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown mw-portlet mw-portlet-lang"  >
	<input type="checkbox" id="p-lang-btn-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox mw-interlanguage-selector" aria-label="Go to an article in another language. Available in 81 languages"   >
	<label id="p-lang-btn-label" for="p-lang-btn-checkbox" class="vector-dropdown-label cdx-button cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--weight-quiet cdx-button--action-progressive mw-portlet-lang-heading-81" aria-hidden="true"  ><span class="vector-icon mw-ui-icon-language-progressive mw-ui-icon-wikimedia-language-progressive"></span>

<span class="vector-dropdown-label-text">81 languages</span>
	</label>
	<div class="vector-dropdown-content">

</tr></tbody></table></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1129693374"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1239400231">.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:inline;font-size:88%;font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .navbar-collapse{float:left;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .navbar-boxtext{word-spacing:0}.mw-parser-output .navbar ul{display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::before{margin-right:-0.125em;content:"[ "}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::after{margin-left:-0.125em;content:" ]"}.mw-parser-output .navbar li{word-spacing:-0.125em}.mw-parser-output .navbar a>span,.mw-parser-output .navbar a>abbr{text-decoration:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-mini abbr{font-variant:small-caps;border-bottom:none;text-decoration:none;cursor:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-full{font-size:114%;margin:0 7em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-mini{font-size:114%;margin:0 4em}html.skin-theme-clientpref-night .mw-parser-output .navbar li a abbr{color:var(--color-base)!important}@media(prefers-color-scheme:dark){html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output .navbar li a abbr{color:var(--color-base)!important}}@media print{.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:none!important}}</style><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:US_2024_presidential_elections_series" title="Template:US 2024 presidential elections series"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:US_2024_presidential_elections_series" title="Template talk:US 2024 presidential elections series"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a href="/wiki/Special:EditPage/Template:US_2024_presidential_elections_series" title="Special:EditPage/Template:US 2024 presidential elections series"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election" title="United States presidential election">Presidential elections</a> were held in the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> on November 5, 2024. The <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republican Party</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Ticket_(election)" title="Ticket (election)">ticket</a><a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a>, who served as the 45th <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">president of the United States</a> from 2017 to 2021, and <a href="/wiki/JD_Vance" title="JD Vance">JD Vance</a>, a <a href="/wiki/U.S._senator" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. senator">U.S. senator</a> from <a href="/wiki/Ohio" title="Ohio">Ohio</a>defeated the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)" title="Democratic Party (United States)">Democratic Party</a>'s ticket<a href="/wiki/Kamala_Harris" title="Kamala Harris">Kamala Harris</a>, the incumbent <a href="/wiki/U.S._vice_president" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. vice president">U.S. vice president</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tim_Walz" title="Tim Walz">Tim Walz</a>, the incumbent <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_Minnesota" title="Governor of Minnesota">governor of Minnesota</a>.
</p><p>The incumbent president, Democrat <a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a>, initially <a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden_2024_presidential_campaign" title="Joe Biden 2024 presidential campaign">ran for re-election</a> as the party's <a href="/wiki/Presumptive_nominee" class="mw-redirect" title="Presumptive nominee">presumptive nominee</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> facing little opposition and easily defeating Representative <a href="/wiki/Dean_Phillips" title="Dean Phillips">Dean Phillips</a> of <a href="/wiki/Minnesota" title="Minnesota">Minnesota</a> during the <a href="/wiki/2024_Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries" title="2024 Democratic Party presidential primaries">Democratic primaries</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>5<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> however, what was broadly considered a <a href="/wiki/2024_Joe_Biden%E2%80%93Donald_Trump_presidential_debate" title="2024 Joe BidenDonald Trump presidential debate">poor debate performance</a> in June 2024 intensified <a href="/wiki/Age_and_health_concerns_about_Joe_Biden" title="Age and health concerns about Joe Biden">concerns about his age and health</a>, and led to <a href="/wiki/List_of_Democrats_who_opposed_the_Joe_Biden_2024_presidential_campaign" title="List of Democrats who opposed the Joe Biden 2024 presidential campaign">calls within his party</a> for him to leave the race.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> After initially declining to do so, <a href="/wiki/Withdrawal_of_Joe_Biden_from_the_2024_United_States_presidential_election" title="Withdrawal of Joe Biden from the 2024 United States presidential election">Biden withdrew</a> on July 21, becoming the first eligible incumbent president to withdraw since <a href="/wiki/Withdrawal_of_Lyndon_B._Johnson_from_the_1968_United_States_presidential_election" title="Withdrawal of Lyndon B. Johnson from the 1968 United States presidential election">Lyndon B. Johnson in 1968</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Biden endorsed Harris,<sup id="cite_ref-NBC_Timeline_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NBC_Timeline-8"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> who was voted <a href="/wiki/Kamala_Harris_2024_presidential_campaign" title="Kamala Harris 2024 presidential campaign">the party's nominee</a> by the delegates on August 5 and became the first nominee who did not participate in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_primary" title="United States presidential primary">primaries</a> since <a href="/wiki/Hubert_Humphrey_1968_presidential_campaign" title="Hubert Humphrey 1968 presidential campaign">Hubert Humphrey, also in 1968</a>. Harris <a href="/wiki/2024_Democratic_Party_vice_presidential_candidate_selection" title="2024 Democratic Party vice presidential candidate selection">selected Walz as her running mate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> 
</p><p>Trump, who lost <a href="/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election" title="2020 United States presidential election">the 2020 presidential election</a> to Biden, <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_2024_presidential_campaign" title="Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign">ran for reelection</a> to a nonconsecutive second term. He was shot in the ear in <a href="/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Donald_Trump_in_Pennsylvania" title="Attempted assassination of Donald Trump in Pennsylvania">an assassination attempt</a> on July 13, 2024. Trump was nominated as the Republican Party's presidential candidate during the <a href="/wiki/2024_Republican_National_Convention" title="2024 Republican National Convention">2024 Republican National Convention</a> alongside his running mate, Vance. <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_2024_presidential_campaign" title="Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign">The Trump campaign</a> ticket supported mass deportation of undocumented immigrants;<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>a<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> an <a href="/wiki/Isolationism" title="Isolationism">isolationist</a> "<a href="/wiki/America_First" title="America First">America First</a>" foreign policy agenda with support of Israel in the <a href="/wiki/Gaza_war" title="Gaza war">Gaza war</a> and skepticism of Ukraine in its <a href="/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="Russian invasion of Ukraine">war with Russia</a>; <a href="/wiki/Transphobia_in_the_United_States" title="Transphobia in the United States">anti-transgender policies</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Tariffs_in_the_second_Trump_administration" title="Tariffs in the second Trump administration">tariffs</a>. The campaign also made <a href="/wiki/False_or_misleading_statements_by_Donald_Trump" title="False or misleading statements by Donald Trump">false and misleading statements</a>, including <a href="/wiki/False_claims_of_fraud_in_the_2020_presidential_election" class="mw-redirect" title="False claims of fraud in the 2020 presidential election">claims of electoral fraud in 2020</a>. <a href="/wiki/Trumpism" title="Trumpism">Trump's political movement</a> was seen by some historians and some former <a href="/wiki/First_cabinet_of_Donald_Trump" title="First cabinet of Donald Trump">Trump administrators</a> as <a href="/wiki/Authoritarian" class="mw-redirect" title="Authoritarian">authoritarian</a>.
</p><p>Trump won the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Electoral_College" title="United States Electoral College">Electoral College</a> with 312 electoral votes to Harris' 226. Trump won every <a href="/wiki/Swing_state" title="Swing state">swing state</a>, including the first win of <a href="/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election_in_Nevada" title="2024 United States presidential election in Nevada">Nevada</a> by Republicans since <a href="/wiki/2004_United_States_presidential_election_in_Nevada" title="2004 United States presidential election in Nevada">2004</a>. Trump won the national <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_presidential_elections_by_popular_vote_margin" title="List of United States presidential elections by popular vote margin">popular vote</a> with a <a href="/wiki/Plurality_(voting)" title="Plurality (voting)">plurality</a> of 49.8%, making him the first Republican to win the popular vote since <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a> in <a href="/wiki/2004_United_States_presidential_election" title="2004 United States presidential election">2004</a>. Trump became the first person since Democrat <a href="/wiki/Grover_Cleveland" title="Grover Cleveland">Grover Cleveland</a> in <a href="/wiki/1892_United_States_presidential_election" title="1892 United States presidential election">1892</a> (and the second person overall) to be elected to a nonconsecutive second term as president of the United States. Analysts attributed the outcome to the <a href="/wiki/2021%E2%80%932023_inflation_surge" title="20212023 inflation surge">20212023 inflation surge</a>, a global anti-incumbent wave, the unpopularity of the <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Joe_Biden" title="Presidency of Joe Biden">Biden administration</a>, and Trump's gains with the working class.
</p>
<meta property="mw:PageProp/toc">
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Background">Background</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election#Procedure" title="United States presidential election">United States presidential election &nbsp;Procedure</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Absentee_Ballot,_2024.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Absentee_Ballot%2C_2024.jpg/250px-Absentee_Ballot%2C_2024.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="188" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Absentee_Ballot%2C_2024.jpg/500px-Absentee_Ballot%2C_2024.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4032" data-file-height="3024"></a><figcaption>A general election absentee ballot from <a href="/wiki/Fairfax_County,_Virginia" title="Fairfax County, Virginia">Fairfax County, Virginia</a>, listing the presidential and vice presidential candidates</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Joe_Biden_presidential_portrait.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Joe_Biden_presidential_portrait.jpg/250px-Joe_Biden_presidential_portrait.jpg" decoding="async" width="190" height="238" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Joe_Biden_presidential_portrait.jpg/330px-Joe_Biden_presidential_portrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Joe_Biden_presidential_portrait.jpg/500px-Joe_Biden_presidential_portrait.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2400" data-file-height="3000"></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Incumbent" title="Incumbent">incumbent</a> president, <a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a>. His term expired at noon on January 20, 2025.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In 2020, incumbent Republican President Donald Trump sought re-election, but was defeated by Democratic challenger Joe Biden. Democratic U.S. Senator Kamala Harris of California was elected vice president in 2020 as Biden's running mate.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Trump is the first president in American history to be <a href="/wiki/Efforts_to_impeach_Donald_Trump" title="Efforts to impeach Donald Trump">impeached twice</a>, and the first to run for president again after impeachment. As Trump was acquitted by the Senate in both cases, he was not barred from seeking reelection to the presidency in 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:USA_electoral_votes_2024_hex_cartogram.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/USA_electoral_votes_2024_hex_cartogram.svg/250px-USA_electoral_votes_2024_hex_cartogram.svg.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="156" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/USA_electoral_votes_2024_hex_cartogram.svg/500px-USA_electoral_votes_2024_hex_cartogram.svg.png 1.5x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="320"></a><figcaption>Hexagonal <a href="/wiki/Cartogram" title="Cartogram">cartogram</a> of the number of electoral college votes. States with opposite outcomes from <a href="/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election" title="2020 United States presidential election">2020</a> are <a href="/wiki/Hatching" title="Hatching">hatched</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Election_interference">Election interference</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Election_interference" title="Election interference">Election interference</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Republican_efforts_to_restrict_voting_following_the_2020_presidential_election" class="mw-redirect" title="Republican efforts to restrict voting following the 2020 presidential election">Republican efforts to restrict voting following the 2020 presidential election</a>, <a href="/wiki/Attempts_to_overturn_the_2020_United_States_presidential_election" title="Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election">Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election</a>, <a href="/wiki/January_6_United_States_Capitol_attack" title="January 6 United States Capitol attack">January 6 United States Capitol attack</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Presidential_eligibility_of_Donald_Trump" title="Presidential eligibility of Donald Trump">Presidential eligibility of Donald Trump</a></div>
<p>Several state courts and officials, including the <a href="/wiki/Colorado_Supreme_Court" title="Colorado Supreme Court">Colorado Supreme Court</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> a state Circuit Court in <a href="/wiki/Illinois" title="Illinois">Illinois</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Secretary_of_State_of_Maine" title="Secretary of State of Maine">Secretary of State of Maine</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Kazarian,_Grace-2023_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kazarian,_Grace-2023-17"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> ruled that <a href="/wiki/2024_presidential_eligibility_of_Donald_Trump" class="mw-redirect" title="2024 presidential eligibility of Donald Trump">Trump was ineligible to hold office</a> under Section 3 of the <a href="/wiki/Fourteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution" title="Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution">Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution</a> for his role in the <a href="/wiki/January_6_Capitol_attack" class="mw-redirect" title="January 6 Capitol attack">January 6 Capitol attack</a>, and thus attempted to disqualify him from appearing on the ballot.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Kazarian,_Grace-2023_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kazarian,_Grace-2023-17"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> These attempts were unsuccessful. On March 4, 2024, the U.S. Supreme Court unanimously ruled in <i><a href="/wiki/Trump_v._Anderson" title="Trump v. Anderson">Trump v. Anderson</a></i> that states cannot determine eligibility for a national election under Section 3. The Court held that only Congress has the authority to disqualify candidates, or to pass legislation that allows courts to do so.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>18<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Donald_Trump's_false_claims_of_interference"><span id="Donald_Trump.27s_false_claims_of_interference"></span>Donald Trump's false claims of interference</h4></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Big_lie#Donald_Trump's_false_claims_of_a_stolen_election" title="Big lie">Big lie &nbsp;Donald Trump's false claims of a stolen election</a>, <a href="/wiki/Election_denial_movement_in_the_United_States" title="Election denial movement in the United States">Election denial movement in the United States</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_efforts_to_disrupt_the_2024_United_States_presidential_election" title="Republican Party efforts to disrupt the 2024 United States presidential election">Republican Party efforts to disrupt the 2024 United States presidential election</a></div>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:20240524_Trump_groundwork_for_election_denial.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/20240524_Trump_groundwork_for_election_denial.svg/250px-20240524_Trump_groundwork_for_election_denial.svg.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/20240524_Trump_groundwork_for_election_denial.svg/330px-20240524_Trump_groundwork_for_election_denial.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/20240524_Trump_groundwork_for_election_denial.svg/500px-20240524_Trump_groundwork_for_election_denial.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="750"></a><figcaption>To sow election doubt, Trump escalated use of "rigged election" and "election interference" statements in advance of the 2024 election compared to the previous two elections.<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-6_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-6-20"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>19<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>Trump made <a href="/wiki/False_claims_of_voter_fraud_in_the_2020_presidential_election" class="mw-redirect" title="False claims of voter fraud in the 2020 presidential election">false claims of voter fraud in the 2020 presidential election</a> and denied the validity of the election results.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>20<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In July 2024, <i>The New York Times</i> reported that "the Republican Party and its conservative allies are engaged in an unprecedented legal campaign targeting the American voting system", by restricting voting for partisan advantage ahead of Election Day and preparing to mount "legally dubious" challenges against the certification process if Trump were to lose.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In the lead-up to the 2024 election, the Republican Party made false claims of massive "noncitizen voting" by immigrants in an attempt to delegitimize the election in the event of a Trump defeat.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>24<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>25<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The claims were made as part of larger Republican Party efforts to disrupt the 2024 election and <a href="/wiki/Election_denial" class="mw-redirect" title="Election denial">election denial</a> movement.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>26<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump and several other Republicans stated that they would not accept the results of the 2024 election if they believe they are "unfair".<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>27<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Trump's previous comments suggesting he could "terminate" the Constitution to reverse his election loss,<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>29<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> his claim that he would only be a dictator on "day one" of his presidency and not afterwards,<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> his promise to use the Justice Department to go after his political enemies,<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>31<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> his plan to use the <a href="/wiki/Insurrection_Act_of_1807" title="Insurrection Act of 1807">Insurrection Act of 1807</a> to deploy the military for law enforcement in primarily Democratic cities and states,<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Attempts_to_overturn_the_2020_United_States_presidential_election" title="Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election">attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election</a>, his baseless predictions of voter fraud in the 2024 election,<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and his public embrace and celebration of the <a href="/wiki/January_6_United_States_Capitol_attack" title="January 6 United States Capitol attack">January 6 United States Capitol attack</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> raised <a href="/wiki/Concerns_over_the_state_of_democracy_in_the_United_States" class="mw-redirect" title="Concerns over the state of democracy in the United States">concerns over the state of democracy in the United States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-trump-dictatorship_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-trump-dictatorship-37"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>36<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>37<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>38<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>39<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump's political operation said that it planned to deploy more than 100,000 attorneys and volunteers to polling places across battleground states, with an "election integrity hotline" for poll watchers and voters to report alleged voting irregularities.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>40<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Interference_by_foreign_nations">Interference by foreign nations</h4></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_interference_in_the_2024_United_States_elections" title="Foreign interference in the 2024 United States elections">Foreign interference in the 2024 United States elections</a></div>
<p>Before the election, U.S. officials and former officials stated that foreign interference in the 2024 election was likely. Three major factors cited were "America's deepening domestic political crises, the collapse of controversial attempts to control political speech on social media, and the rise of <a href="/wiki/Generative_AI" class="mw-redirect" title="Generative AI">generative AI</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>41<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> China, Russia, and Iran were identified as mounting influence operations and attempts to interfere with the 2024 election. U.S. intelligence officials described the efforts as part of broader efforts by authoritarian nations to use the internet to erode support for democracy.<sup id="cite_ref-Klepper_09032024_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Klepper_09032024-43"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>42<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading5"><h5 id="China">China</h5></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Chinese_interference_in_the_2024_United_States_elections" title="Chinese interference in the 2024 United States elections">Chinese interference in the 2024 United States elections</a></div>
<p>China was identified as interfering with the 2024 election through propaganda and disinformation campaigns linked to its <a href="/wiki/Spamouflage" title="Spamouflage">Spamouflage</a> operation. U.S. intelligence agencies described the effort as not targeting any particular candidate but focusing on issues important to the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_government" class="mw-redirect" title="Chinese government">Chinese government</a>, such as Taiwan, and "undermining confidence in elections, voting, and the U.S. in general".<sup id="cite_ref-Klepper_09032024_43-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Klepper_09032024-43"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>42<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As early as April 1, 2024, <i>The New York Times</i> reported that the Chinese government had created fake pro-Trump accounts on social media "promoting conspiracy theories, stoking domestic divisions and attacking President Biden ahead of the election in November".<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading5"><h5 id="Russia">Russia</h5></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Russian_interference_in_the_2024_United_States_elections" title="Russian interference in the 2024 United States elections">Russian interference in the 2024 United States elections</a></div>
<p>According to disinformation experts and intelligence agencies, Russia spread disinformation ahead of the 2024 election to damage Biden and Democrats, boost candidates supporting isolationism, and undercut support for Ukraine aid and NATO.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>45<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On September 4, 2024, the United States publicly accused Russia of interfering in the 2024 election and announced several steps to combat Russian influence including <a href="/wiki/International_sanctions_during_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="International sanctions during the Russian invasion of Ukraine">sanctions</a>, indictments, and seizing of web domains used to spread propaganda and disinformation. U.S. intelligence agencies assessed that Russia preferred Trump to win the election, viewing him as more critical of American support for Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>46<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading5"><h5 id="Iran">Iran</h5></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Iranian_interference_in_the_2024_United_States_elections" title="Iranian interference in the 2024 United States elections">Iranian interference in the 2024 United States elections</a></div>
<p>Iran was identified as interfering with the 2024 presidential election through front companies connected to the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Revolutionary_Guard_Corps" title="Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps">Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps</a> and hacking attempts against the Trump, Biden, and Harris campaigns starting as early as May 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-USA_Today-2024_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USA_Today-2024-48"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>47<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Iran launched propaganda and disinformation campaigns through fake news websites and accounts on social media to tip the election against former president Trump. <i>The New York Times</i> stated the efforts were an attempt at "sowing internal discord and discrediting the democratic system in the United States more broadly in the eyes of the world".<sup id="cite_ref-USA_Today-2024_48-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USA_Today-2024-48"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>47<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>48<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>49<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Voter_roll_purges">Voter roll purges</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Republican_efforts_to_restrict_voting_following_the_2020_presidential_election" class="mw-redirect" title="Republican efforts to restrict voting following the 2020 presidential election">Republican efforts to restrict voting following the 2020 presidential election</a></div>
<p>Multiple Republican-led administrations removed voters from their states' voter rolls in the lead up to the election, which critics argued violates the <a href="/wiki/National_Voter_Registration_Act_of_1993" title="National Voter Registration Act of 1993">National Voter Registration Act</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-guardianaug30_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guardianaug30-52"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>52<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In July 2024, 160,000 inactive or infrequent voters were removed from <a href="/wiki/Ohio" title="Ohio">Ohio</a>'s voter rolls.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>53<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>54<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Ohio chapters of <a href="/wiki/Common_Cause" title="Common Cause">Common Cause</a> and the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Women_Voters" title="League of Women Voters">League of Women Voters</a> threatened lawsuits against the state over the purge.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>56<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In August 2024, Governor <a href="/wiki/Glenn_Youngkin" title="Glenn Youngkin">Glenn Youngkin</a> of <a href="/wiki/Virginia" title="Virginia">Virginia</a> signed an executive order removing 6,303 voters suspected of being non-citizens from Virginia's voter rolls.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>58<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In October 2024, the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Department_of_Justice" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Department of Justice">U.S. Department of Justice</a> sued the Virginia Board of Elections and Virginia commissioner of elections over the voter purge, alleging that it violated the <a href="/wiki/National_Voter_Registration_Act" class="mw-redirect" title="National Voter Registration Act">National Voter Registration Act</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-JD_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JD-61"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>60<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The suit also found a number of alleged non-citizens purged were actually citizens.<sup id="cite_ref-JD_61-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JD-61"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>60<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AC_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AC-62"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> District judge <a href="/wiki/Patricia_Tolliver_Giles" title="Patricia Tolliver Giles">Patricia Tolliver Giles</a> ruled that the removal was illegal, ordering the state to stop purging voter rolls and to restore the voter registration of more than 1,600 voters who had been removed.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>62<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AC_62-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AC-62"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/4th_Circuit_Court_of_Appeals" class="mw-redirect" title="4th Circuit Court of Appeals">4th Circuit Court of Appeals</a> then upheld the order.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>63<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CP_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CP-65"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>64<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The administration filed an emergency appeal to the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Supreme_Court" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Supreme Court">U.S. Supreme Court</a>, which sided with Virginia in a 63 decision <a href="/wiki/Ideological_leanings_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_justices" title="Ideological leanings of United States Supreme Court justices">along ideological lines</a>, allowing the state to continue purging voter rolls.<sup id="cite_ref-CP_65-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CP-65"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>64<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>65<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In August 2024, <a href="/wiki/Alabama" title="Alabama">Alabama</a> Secretary of State <a href="/wiki/Wes_Allen_(politician)" title="Wes Allen (politician)">Wes Allen</a> announced a process for purging 3,251 registered Alabama voters and referred them to the state attorney general's office for criminal prosecution.<sup id="cite_ref-guardianaug30_52-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guardianaug30-52"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>66<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In September 2024, the Department of Justice sued Alabama for violating the National Voter Registration Act.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>67<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In October 2024, district judge <a href="/wiki/Anna_Manasco" class="mw-redirect" title="Anna Manasco">Anna Manasco</a> ruled in favor of the Department of Justice, ordering the state to restore the voter registrations.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FJ_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FJ-71"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Alabama secretary of state's chief of staff Clay Helms testified that 2,000 of the purged voters were legally registered citizens.<sup id="cite_ref-FJ_71-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FJ-71"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Criminal_and_civil_legal_proceedings_involving_Donald_Trump">Criminal and civil legal proceedings involving Donald Trump</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Indictments_against_Donald_Trump" title="Indictments against Donald Trump">Indictments against Donald Trump</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Federal_prosecution_of_Donald_Trump_(election_obstruction_case)" title="Federal prosecution of Donald Trump (election obstruction case)">Federal prosecution of Donald Trump (election obstruction case)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georgia_election_racketeering_prosecution" title="Georgia election racketeering prosecution">Georgia election racketeering prosecution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federal_prosecution_of_Donald_Trump_(classified_documents_case)" title="Federal prosecution of Donald Trump (classified documents case)">Federal prosecution of Donald Trump (classified documents case)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prosecution_of_Donald_Trump_in_New_York" title="Prosecution of Donald Trump in New York">Prosecution of Donald Trump in New York</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Personal_and_business_legal_affairs_of_Donald_Trump" title="Personal and business legal affairs of Donald Trump">Personal and business legal affairs of Donald Trump</a></div>
<p>Trump was the subject of various criminal and civil legal proceedings before and during his 2024 re-election campaign. Specifically, Trump was found liable in a civil proceeding for <a href="/wiki/Financial_fraud" class="mw-redirect" title="Financial fraud">financial fraud</a> in 2023,<sup id="cite_ref-hushhush_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hushhush-72"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> was found liable for both <a href="/wiki/Sexual_abuse" title="Sexual abuse">sexual abuse</a> and <a href="/wiki/Defamation" title="Defamation">defamation</a> in 2023, and was found liable for defamation in a related civil proceeding in 2024. In 2024, Trump was criminally convicted of 34 <a href="/wiki/Felonies" class="mw-redirect" title="Felonies">felonies</a> related to <a href="/wiki/Falsifying_business_records" title="Falsifying business records">falsifying business records</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump and other Republicans made numerous false and misleading statements regarding Trump's various legal proceedings, including false claims that they were "rigged" or consisted of "election interference" orchestrated by Biden and the Democratic Party.<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-4_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-4-74"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>73<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-6_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-6-20"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>19<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Classified_intelligence_material_found_during_search_of_Mar-a-Lago.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Classified_intelligence_material_found_during_search_of_Mar-a-Lago.jpg/250px-Classified_intelligence_material_found_during_search_of_Mar-a-Lago.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="166" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Classified_intelligence_material_found_during_search_of_Mar-a-Lago.jpg/500px-Classified_intelligence_material_found_during_search_of_Mar-a-Lago.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3717" data-file-height="2473"></a><figcaption>Classified intelligence material found inside <a href="/wiki/Mar-a-Lago" title="Mar-a-Lago">Mar-a-Lago</a> in 2022</figcaption></figure>
<p>On May 30, 2024, Trump was found guilty by a jury of all 34 felony counts in <i><a href="/wiki/The_People_of_the_State_of_New_York_v._Donald_J._Trump" class="mw-redirect" title="The People of the State of New York v. Donald J. Trump">The People of the State of New York v. Donald J. Trump</a></i>. The jury found that Trump falsified business records relating to <a href="/wiki/Hush_money" title="Hush money">hush money</a> payments made to pornographic film star <a href="/wiki/Stormy_Daniels" title="Stormy Daniels">Stormy Daniels</a> to ensure her silence about <a href="/wiki/Stormy_Daniels%E2%80%93Donald_Trump_scandal" title="Stormy DanielsDonald Trump scandal">a sexual encounter between them</a>. This conviction made Trump the first former U.S. president to be convicted of a crime.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On January 10, 2025, Trump was given a no-penalty sentence known as an unconditional discharge.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>75<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Trump faced other criminal charges as well. In <i>United States of America v. Donald J. Trump</i>, Trump faced four criminal counts for his alleged role in <a href="/wiki/Attempting_to_overturn_the_2020_United_States_presidential_election" class="mw-redirect" title="Attempting to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election">attempting to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election</a> and involvement in the <a href="/wiki/January_6_United_States_Capitol_attack" title="January 6 United States Capitol attack">January 6 United States Capitol attack</a>; the case was dismissed following Trump's re-election in November 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In <i><a href="/wiki/The_State_of_Georgia_v._Donald_J._Trump,_et_al." class="mw-redirect" title="The State of Georgia v. Donald J. Trump, et al.">The State of Georgia v. Donald J. Trump, et al.</a></i>, Trump was charged with eight criminal counts for his alleged attempts to overturn the results of the <a href="/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election_in_Georgia" title="2020 United States presidential election in Georgia">2020 United States presidential election in Georgia</a>. District Attorney Fani Willis was disqualified from prosecuting the case; Willis has appealed that decision.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In <i>United States of America v. Donald J. Trump, Waltine Nauta, and Carlos De Oliveira</i>, Trump faced 40 criminal counts relating to his <a href="/wiki/FBI_search_of_Mar-a-Lago" title="FBI search of Mar-a-Lago">hoarding of classified documents</a> and alleged obstruction of efforts to retrieve them;<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> the case was dismissed in July 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On May 9, 2023, in <i><a href="/wiki/E._Jean_Carroll_v._Donald_J._Trump" title="E. Jean Carroll v. Donald J. Trump">E. Jean Carroll v. Donald J. Trump</a></i>, an anonymous jury found Trump civilly liable<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>80<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> for sexual abuse and defamation, and ordered him to pay Carroll $5 million in damages.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In a related case brought by Carroll against Trump, a jury awarded Carroll $83.3&nbsp;million.<sup id="cite_ref-:27_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:27-83"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>82<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As of April 2025, appeals were ongoing in both cases.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>83<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In September 2023, Trump was found civilly liable for <a href="/wiki/Financial_fraud" class="mw-redirect" title="Financial fraud">financial fraud</a> in <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_business_fraud_lawsuit_against_the_Trump_Organization" title="New York business fraud lawsuit against the Trump Organization">New York v. Trump</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-hushhush_72-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hushhush-72"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In February 2024, he was ordered to pay a $354.8 million fine, together with approximately $100 million in interest.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>84<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As of January 29, 2025, an appeal was ongoing.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>85<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Trump made efforts to delay his trials until after the 2024 election.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>86<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>87<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On July 1, 2024, the Supreme Court delivered a 63 decision in <i><a href="/wiki/Trump_v._United_States_(2024)" class="mw-redirect" title="Trump v. United States (2024)">Trump v. United States</a></i>, ruling that Trump had absolute immunity for acts he committed as president within his core constitutional purview, at least presumptive immunity for official acts within the outer perimeter of his official responsibility, and no immunity for unofficial acts.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>88<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>89<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>90<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Age_and_health_concerns">Age and health concerns</h3></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Joe_Biden">Joe Biden</h4></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Age_and_health_concerns_about_Joe_Biden" title="Age and health concerns about Joe Biden">Age and health concerns about Joe Biden</a></div>
<p>Mass media, lawmakers, and Donald Trump raised concerns about President Biden's age, including his cognitive state, during and after the <a href="/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election" title="2020 United States presidential election">2020 United States presidential election</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BAge_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BAge-92"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>91<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> According to a February 2024 poll, Biden's age and health were major or moderate concerns for 86% of voters generally,<sup id="cite_ref-BAge_92-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BAge-92"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>91<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> up from 76% in 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>92<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> According to another February 2024 poll, most of those who voted for Biden in 2020 believed he was too old to be an effective president; <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> noted that these concerns "cut across generations, gender, race and education".<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>93<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Concerns about Biden's age and health increased after a poor performance by Biden during <a href="/wiki/June_2024_United_States_presidential_debate" class="mw-redirect" title="June 2024 United States presidential debate">a debate against Trump</a> in June 2024. That performance led a number of commentators and Democratic lawmakers to call for Biden to drop out of the 2024 presidential race.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>94<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In July 2024, <a href="/wiki/Biden_withdrew" class="mw-redirect" title="Biden withdrew">Biden withdrew</a> his candidacy while stating that he would continue serving as president until the conclusion of his term.<sup id="cite_ref-wp-election-2024_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wp-election-2024-96"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Donald_Trump">Donald Trump</h4></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Age_and_health_concerns_about_Donald_Trump" title="Age and health concerns about Donald Trump">Age and health concerns about Donald Trump</a></div>
<p>In the summer before the election, polling showed at least half of Americans thought that Trump, who was 78 years old, was too old to serve a second term, with 80% unsure he would be able to finish out a second term.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Independent-2024_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Independent-2024-97"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>96<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Numerous public figures, media sources, and mental health professionals speculated that Trump may have some form of <a href="/wiki/Dementia" title="Dementia">dementia</a>, which runs in his family.<sup id="cite_ref-wapojuly22_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wapojuly22-98"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>97<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Experts for the science publication <i><a href="/wiki/Stat_(website)" title="Stat (website)">STAT</a></i> who analyzed changes in Trump's speeches between 2015 and 2024 noted shorter sentences, more tangents, more repetition, and more confusion of words and phrases. Doctors suggested these changes could relate to Trump's moods or could indicate the beginning of <a href="/wiki/Alzheimer%27s" class="mw-redirect" title="Alzheimer's">Alzheimer's</a>. One expert noted an increase in expressions of all-or-nothing thinking by Trump. A sharp rise in <a href="/wiki/All-or-nothing_thinking" class="mw-redirect" title="All-or-nothing thinking">all-or-nothing thinking</a> is also linked to <a href="/wiki/Cognitive_decline" class="mw-redirect" title="Cognitive decline">cognitive decline</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_Republic-2024_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_Republic-2024-99"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>98<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i>The New York Times</i> reported that Trump's 2024 speeches had grown "darker, harsher, longer, angrier, less focused, more profane and increasingly fixated on the past", and that experts considered this increase in <a href="/wiki/Tangential_speech" title="Tangential speech">tangential speech</a> and <a href="/wiki/Behavioral_disinhibition" class="mw-redirect" title="Behavioral disinhibition">behavioral disinhibition</a> as a possible consequence of advancing age and cognitive decline.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>99<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump was also criticized for his lack of transparency around his medical records and health.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>100<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wapojuly22_98-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wapojuly22-98"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>97<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Violent_rhetoric">Violent rhetoric</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Political_violence_in_the_2024_United_States_presidential_election" title="Political violence in the 2024 United States presidential election">Political violence in the 2024 United States presidential election</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_2024_presidential_campaign#Violent_and_dehumanizing_statements" title="Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign">Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign &nbsp;Violent and dehumanizing statements</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><span><video id="mwe_player_0" poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_14%2C_2024_%28no_ASL%29.webm/250px--President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_14%2C_2024_%28no_ASL%29.webm.jpg" controls="" preload="none" data-mw-tmh="" class="mw-file-element" width="250" height="141" data-durationhint="384" data-mwtitle="President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation,_July_14,_2024_(no_ASL).webm" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" resource="/wiki/File:President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation,_July_14,_2024_(no_ASL).webm"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/6/6a/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_14%2C_2024_%28no_ASL%29.webm/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_14%2C_2024_%28no_ASL%29.webm.480p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-transcodekey="480p.vp9.webm" data-width="854" data-height="480"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/6/6a/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_14%2C_2024_%28no_ASL%29.webm/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_14%2C_2024_%28no_ASL%29.webm.720p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-transcodekey="720p.vp9.webm" data-width="1280" data-height="720"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6a/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_14%2C_2024_%28no_ASL%29.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-width="1920" data-height="1080"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/6/6a/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_14%2C_2024_%28no_ASL%29.webm/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_14%2C_2024_%28no_ASL%29.webm.1080p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-transcodekey="1080p.vp9.webm" data-width="1920" data-height="1080"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/6/6a/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_14%2C_2024_%28no_ASL%29.webm/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_14%2C_2024_%28no_ASL%29.webm.144p.mjpeg.mov" type="video/quicktime" data-transcodekey="144p.mjpeg.mov" data-width="256" data-height="144"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/6/6a/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_14%2C_2024_%28no_ASL%29.webm/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_14%2C_2024_%28no_ASL%29.webm.240p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-transcodekey="240p.vp9.webm" data-width="426" data-height="240"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/6/6a/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_14%2C_2024_%28no_ASL%29.webm/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_14%2C_2024_%28no_ASL%29.webm.360p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-transcodekey="360p.vp9.webm" data-width="640" data-height="360"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/6/6a/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_14%2C_2024_%28no_ASL%29.webm/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_14%2C_2024_%28no_ASL%29.webm.360p.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp8, vorbis&quot;" data-transcodekey="360p.webm" data-width="640" data-height="360"><track src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3APresident_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_14%2C_2024_%28no_ASL%29.webm&amp;lang=en&amp;trackformat=vtt&amp;origin=%2A" kind="subtitles" type="text/vtt" srclang="en" label="English (en)" data-dir="ltr"></video></span><figcaption>On July 14, Biden gave an address condemning political violence, including the attempted assassination of Trump, arguing for the need to "lower the temperature" in American politics.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Several scholars, lawmakers, intelligence agencies, and the members of the public expressed concerns about <a href="/wiki/Political_violence" title="Political violence">political violence</a> surrounding the 2024 election.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>101<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>102<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The fears came amidst increasing threats and acts of physical violence targeting public officials and election workers at all levels of government.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>103<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>104<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump was identified as a key figure in increasing political violence in the United States both for and against him.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>105<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Perspectives_on_Terrorism-2020_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Perspectives_on_Terrorism-2020-107"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>106<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-It's_About_Hate-2022_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-It's_About_Hate-2022-108"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>107<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Political violence was at its highest since the 1970s, and the most recent violence came from right-wing assailants.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>108<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>109<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump increasingly embraced <a href="/wiki/Far-right_extremism" class="mw-redirect" title="Far-right extremism">far-right extremism</a>, conspiracy theories such as <a href="/wiki/Q-Anon" class="mw-redirect" title="Q-Anon">Q-Anon</a>, and far-right <a href="/wiki/American_militia_movement" title="American militia movement">militia movements</a> to a greater extent than any modern American president.<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2022_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2022-111"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>110<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_Associated_Press-2023_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Associated_Press-2023-112"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>111<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump also espoused dehumanizing, combative, and violent rhetoric,<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>112<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and promised retribution against his political enemies.<sup id="cite_ref-vows_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vows-114"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>113<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump played down but refused to rule out violence following the 2024 election, stating "it depends".<sup id="cite_ref-IbssaKim2024_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IbssaKim2024-115"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>114<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump also suggested using the military against "the enemy from within" on Election Day that he described as "radical left lunatics", Democratic politicians, and those opposed to his candidacy.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>115<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lerer_10152024_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lerer_10152024-117"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>116<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Nominations">Nominations</h2></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Republican_Party">Republican Party</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/2024_Republican_Party_presidential_primaries" title="2024 Republican Party presidential primaries">2024 Republican Party presidential primaries</a> and <a href="/wiki/2024_Republican_Party_presidential_candidates" title="2024 Republican Party presidential candidates">2024 Republican Party presidential candidates</a></div>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Republican_Party_presidential_primaries_results,_2024.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Republican_Party_presidential_primaries_results%2C_2024.svg/250px-Republican_Party_presidential_primaries_results%2C_2024.svg.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="158" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Republican_Party_presidential_primaries_results%2C_2024.svg/500px-Republican_Party_presidential_primaries_results%2C_2024.svg.png 1.5x" data-file-width="990" data-file-height="627"></a><figcaption>Results of the 2024 Republican presidential primaries. Trump (<i>blue</i>) won everything but Vermont and <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington D.C.</a>, which went to <a href="/wiki/Nikki_Haley" title="Nikki Haley">Nikki Haley</a> (<i>orange</i>).</figcaption></figure>
<p>Trump filed and announced his candidacy a week following the <a href="/wiki/2022_United_States_elections" title="2022 United States elections">2022 midterm elections</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>117<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump was considered an early frontrunner for the Republican presidential nomination.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>118<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> He had announced in March 2022 that his former vice president <a href="/wiki/Mike_Pence" title="Mike Pence">Mike Pence</a> would not be his running mate.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>119<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Trump faced opposition in the primaries. Florida Governor <a href="/wiki/Ron_DeSantis" title="Ron DeSantis">Ron DeSantis</a> was initially viewed as the main challenger to Trump for the Republican nomination, having raised more campaign funds in the first half of 2022 and posting more favorable polling numbers than Trump by the end of 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>120<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>121<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>122<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On May 24, 2023, DeSantis announced his candidacy on Twitter in an online conversation with Twitter CEO <a href="/wiki/Elon_Musk" title="Elon Musk">Elon Musk</a>. At the end of July 2023, <i><a href="/wiki/FiveThirtyEight" title="FiveThirtyEight">FiveThirtyEight</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s national polling average of the Republican primaries had Trump at 52 percent, and DeSantis at 15.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>123<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Following the <a href="/wiki/2024_Iowa_Republican_presidential_caucuses" title="2024 Iowa Republican presidential caucuses">Iowa caucuses</a>, in which Trump posted a landslide victory, DeSantis and businessman <a href="/wiki/Vivek_Ramaswamy" title="Vivek Ramaswamy">Vivek Ramaswamy</a> dropped out of the race and endorsed Trump, leaving the former president and <a href="/wiki/Nikki_Haley" title="Nikki Haley">Nikki Haley</a>, the former South Carolina governor who served in <a href="/wiki/First_cabinet_of_Donald_Trump" title="First cabinet of Donald Trump">Trump's cabinet</a>, as the only remaining major candidates.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>124<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>125<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump continued to win all four early voting contests while Haley's campaign struggled to gain momentum.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>126<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On March 6, 2024, the day after winning only one primary out of fifteen on <a href="/wiki/2024_Super_Tuesday" class="mw-redirect" title="2024 Super Tuesday">Super Tuesday</a>, Haley suspended her campaign.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>127<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>128<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On March 12, 2024, Trump officially became the presumptive Republican presidential nominee.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>129<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump was injured in <a href="/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Donald_Trump_in_Pennsylvania" title="Attempted assassination of Donald Trump in Pennsylvania">an assassination attempt</a> on July 13, 2024, when a bullet grazed his ear.<sup id="cite_ref-CNNAssassinationUnfold_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNNAssassinationUnfold-131"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>130<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This was the first time a president or major party presidential candidate was injured in an assassination attempt since <a href="/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan" title="Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan in 1981</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-TownAndCountryAttempts_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TownAndCountryAttempts-132"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>131<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On July 15, 2024, the first day of the <a href="/wiki/2024_Republican_National_Convention" title="2024 Republican National Convention">Republican National Convention</a>, Trump officially announced that Senator <a href="/wiki/JD_Vance" title="JD Vance">JD Vance</a> of Ohio would be his running mate.<sup id="cite_ref-Hill-0715_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hill-0715-133"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>132<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On July 18, 2024, for the third consecutive time, Trump accepted the nomination from the Republican National Convention to become the Republican presidential nominee.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>133<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>

<hr>
<div class="hidden-begin mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" style=""><div class="hidden-title skin-nightmode-reset-color" style=""><a href="/wiki/Political_positions_of_Donald_Trump" title="Political positions of Donald Trump">Policies</a></div><div class="hidden-content mw-collapsible-content" style="text-align:center;">
<ul><li>Domestic

<td><figure class="mw-halign-center" typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Francis_Suarez_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Francis_Suarez_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg/120px-Francis_Suarez_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg" decoding="async" width="91" height="120" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Francis_Suarez_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg/250px-Francis_Suarez_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2967" data-file-height="3911"></a><figcaption></figcaption></figure>

<td><sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>158<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>159<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
