<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Democratic_Party">Democratic Party</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/2024_Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries" title="2024 Democratic Party presidential primaries">2024 Democratic Party presidential primaries</a> and <a href="/wiki/2024_Democratic_Party_presidential_candidates" title="2024 Democratic Party presidential candidates">2024 Democratic Party presidential candidates</a></div>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries_results_by_delegate_allocation,_2024.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries_results_by_delegate_allocation%2C_2024.svg/250px-Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries_results_by_delegate_allocation%2C_2024.svg.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="158" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries_results_by_delegate_allocation%2C_2024.svg/500px-Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries_results_by_delegate_allocation%2C_2024.svg.png 1.5x" data-file-width="990" data-file-height="627"></a><figcaption>Results of the 2024 Democratic presidential primaries. Biden (<i>blue</i>) won everything but <a href="/wiki/American_Samoa" title="American Samoa">American Samoa</a>, which went to <a href="/wiki/Jason_Palmer_(politician)" title="Jason Palmer (politician)">Jason Palmer</a> (<i>purple</i>).</figcaption></figure>
<p>On April 25, 2023, President Biden officially announced his <a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden_2024_presidential_campaign" title="Joe Biden 2024 presidential campaign">bid for re-election</a>, confirming that Vice President Harris would remain his running mate.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>160<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>161<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Concerns about Biden's age were prominent, given that he was <a href="/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States_by_age" title="List of presidents of the United States by age">the oldest person to assume the office</a> at age 78, which would make him 82 at the end of his first term and 86 at the end of a potential second term.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>162<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> An April 2023 poll indicated that 70 percent of Americans, including 51 percent of Democrats, believed Biden should not seek a second term, with nearly half citing his age as the reason. Biden's approval rating stood at 41 percent, with 55 percent disapproving.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>163<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Speculation also arose that Biden might face a primary challenge from the <a href="/wiki/Factions_in_the_Democratic_Party_(United_States)#Progressives" title="Factions in the Democratic Party (United States)">Democratic Party's progressive faction</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>164<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>165<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> however, after Democrats outperformed expectations in the <a href="/wiki/2022_midterm_elections" class="mw-redirect" title="2022 midterm elections">2022 midterm elections</a>, many believed Biden's chances of securing the party's nomination had increased.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>166<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>  On July 28, 2022, Representative <a href="/wiki/Dean_Phillips" title="Dean Phillips">Dean Phillips</a> of <a href="/wiki/Minnesota" title="Minnesota">Minnesota</a> became the first incumbent Democratic member of Congress to say President Biden should not run for re-election and called for "generational change" pointing to Biden's age.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>167<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>168<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Despite a handful of primary challengers, including Representative Dean Phillips, <a href="/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy_Jr." title="Robert F. Kennedy Jr.">Robert F. Kennedy Jr.</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marianne_Williamson" title="Marianne Williamson">Marianne Williamson</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jason_Palmer_(politician)" title="Jason Palmer (politician)">Jason Palmer</a>, Biden easily became the presumptive nominee of the party on March 12, 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>169<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>170<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>171<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Palmer, who won the <a href="/wiki/2024_American_Samoa_Democratic_presidential_caucuses" title="2024 American Samoa Democratic presidential caucuses">American Samoa caucuses</a>, became the first candidate to win a contested primary against an incumbent president since <a href="/wiki/Ted_Kennedy" title="Ted Kennedy">Ted Kennedy</a> in 1980.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>172<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Biden also faced significant opposition from <a href="/wiki/Uncommitted_(voting_option)" title="Uncommitted (voting option)">uncommitted voters</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Uncommitted_National_Movement" title="Uncommitted National Movement">Uncommitted National Movement</a> in their <a href="/wiki/Gaza_war_protest_vote_movements" title="Gaza war protest vote movements">protest vote movement against Biden</a> due to his support for Israel during the <a href="/wiki/Gaza_war" title="Gaza war">Gaza war</a>, which collectively won 36 delegates.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>173<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><span><video id="mwe_player_1" poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_24%2C_2024_%28Video%29.webm/250px--President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_24%2C_2024_%28Video%29.webm.jpg" controls="" preload="none" data-mw-tmh="" class="mw-file-element" width="250" height="141" data-durationhint="664" data-mwtitle="President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation,_July_24,_2024_(Video).webm" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" resource="/wiki/File:President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation,_July_24,_2024_(Video).webm"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/2/27/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_24%2C_2024_%28Video%29.webm/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_24%2C_2024_%28Video%29.webm.480p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-transcodekey="480p.vp9.webm" data-width="854" data-height="480"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/2/27/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_24%2C_2024_%28Video%29.webm/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_24%2C_2024_%28Video%29.webm.720p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-transcodekey="720p.vp9.webm" data-width="1280" data-height="720"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/27/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_24%2C_2024_%28Video%29.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;av01.0.05M.08, opus&quot;" data-width="1326" data-height="746"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/2/27/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_24%2C_2024_%28Video%29.webm/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_24%2C_2024_%28Video%29.webm.144p.mjpeg.mov" type="video/quicktime" data-transcodekey="144p.mjpeg.mov" data-width="256" data-height="144"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/2/27/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_24%2C_2024_%28Video%29.webm/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_24%2C_2024_%28Video%29.webm.240p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-transcodekey="240p.vp9.webm" data-width="426" data-height="240"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/2/27/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_24%2C_2024_%28Video%29.webm/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_24%2C_2024_%28Video%29.webm.360p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-transcodekey="360p.vp9.webm" data-width="640" data-height="360"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/2/27/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_24%2C_2024_%28Video%29.webm/President_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_24%2C_2024_%28Video%29.webm.360p.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp8, vorbis&quot;" data-transcodekey="360p.webm" data-width="640" data-height="360"><track src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3APresident_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_24%2C_2024_%28Video%29.webm&amp;lang=en&amp;trackformat=vtt&amp;origin=%2A" kind="subtitles" type="text/vtt" srclang="en" label="English (en)" data-dir="ltr"><track src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3APresident_Biden_Addresses_the_Nation%2C_July_24%2C_2024_%28Video%29.webm&amp;lang=ru&amp;trackformat=vtt&amp;origin=%2A" kind="subtitles" type="text/vtt" srclang="ru" label=" (ru)" data-dir="ltr"></video></span><figcaption>On July 24, Biden addressed the nation from the <a href="/wiki/Oval_Office" title="Oval Office">Oval Office</a> on his decision three days earlier to <a href="/wiki/Withdrawal_of_Joe_Biden_from_the_2024_United_States_presidential_election" title="Withdrawal of Joe Biden from the 2024 United States presidential election">withdraw from the race</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Following a "disastrous" June 2024 <a href="/wiki/2024_Joe_Biden%E2%80%93Donald_Trump_presidential_debate" title="2024 Joe BidenDonald Trump presidential debate">debate performance</a> against Trump that "inflamed age concerns",<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>174<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Biden ultimately <a href="/wiki/Withdrawal_of_Joe_Biden_from_the_2024_United_States_presidential_election" title="Withdrawal of Joe Biden from the 2024 United States presidential election">withdrew from the race</a> on July 21, 2024, and immediately endorsed <a href="/wiki/Kamala_Harris" title="Kamala Harris">Kamala Harris</a> as his successor.<sup id="cite_ref-wp-election-2024_96-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wp-election-2024-96"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris quickly announced <a href="/wiki/Kamala_Harris_2024_presidential_campaign" title="Kamala Harris 2024 presidential campaign">her own campaign</a> and secured enough delegate endorsements by July 22 to replace Biden as the presumptive nominee of the party.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>175<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Biden's withdrawal made him the first eligible incumbent president since <a href="/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson" title="Lyndon B. Johnson">Lyndon B. Johnson</a> in <a href="/wiki/Withdrawal_of_Lyndon_B._Johnson_from_the_1968_United_States_presidential_election" title="Withdrawal of Lyndon B. Johnson from the 1968 United States presidential election">1968</a> not to seek re-election, and the first to withdraw after securing enough delegates to win the nomination.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>176<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris is the first nominee who did not participate in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_primary" title="United States presidential primary">presidential primaries</a> since Vice President <a href="/wiki/Hubert_Humphrey" title="Hubert Humphrey">Hubert Humphrey</a>, also in <a href="/wiki/Hubert_Humphrey_1968_presidential_campaign" title="Hubert Humphrey 1968 presidential campaign">1968</a>, and the first since <a href="/wiki/McGovern%E2%80%93Fraser_Commission" title="McGovernFraser Commission">the modern Democratic Party primary procedure was created in 1972</a> (prior to which most states did not hold primary elections).<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>177<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On August 5, 2024, after five days of online balloting, Democratic National Convention delegates voted to make Harris the party's 2024 presidential nominee.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>178<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> She <a href="/wiki/2024_Democratic_Party_vice_presidential_candidate_selection" title="2024 Democratic Party vice presidential candidate selection">selected</a> Minnesota Governor <a href="/wiki/Tim_Walz" title="Tim Walz">Tim Walz</a> as her running mate the following day<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>179<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and accepted the party's nomination on August 22.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>180<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Nominees_2">Nominees</h4></div>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Third-party_and_independent_candidates">Third-party and independent candidates</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Third-party_and_independent_candidates_for_the_2024_United_States_presidential_election" title="Third-party and independent candidates for the 2024 United States presidential election">Third-party and independent candidates for the 2024 United States presidential election</a></div>
<p>A number of <a href="/wiki/Independent_candidates" class="mw-redirect" title="Independent candidates">independent candidates</a>  announced presidential runs, most notably <a href="/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy_Jr." title="Robert F. Kennedy Jr.">Robert F. Kennedy Jr.</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cornel_West" title="Cornel West">Cornel West</a>. Several third parties, including the <a href="/wiki/Libertarian_Party_(United_States)" title="Libertarian Party (United States)">Libertarian Party</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Green_Party_of_the_United_States" title="Green Party of the United States">Green Party</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Party_for_Socialism_and_Liberation" title="Party for Socialism and Liberation">Party for Socialism and Liberation</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_Party_(United_States)" title="Constitution Party (United States)">Constitution Party</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/American_Solidarity_Party" title="American Solidarity Party">American Solidarity Party</a> also announced presidential nominees.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>186<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Kennedy dropped out of the race in August 2024, although he remained on the ballot in many states. The <a href="/wiki/No_Labels" title="No Labels">No Labels</a> organization abandoned its efforts to run a <a href="/wiki/Centrist" class="mw-redirect" title="Centrist">centrist</a> candidate in April 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>187<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="With_majority_ballot_access">With majority ballot access</h4></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading5"><h5 id="Libertarian_Party">Libertarian Party</h5></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/2024_Libertarian_Party_presidential_primaries" title="2024 Libertarian Party presidential primaries">2024 Libertarian Party presidential primaries</a>, <a href="/wiki/2024_Libertarian_National_Convention" title="2024 Libertarian National Convention">2024 Libertarian National Convention</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chase_Oliver_2024_presidential_campaign" title="Chase Oliver 2024 presidential campaign">Chase Oliver 2024 presidential campaign</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Chase_Oliver" title="Chase Oliver">Chase Oliver</a> was chosen by the <a href="/wiki/Libertarian_Party_(United_States)" title="Libertarian Party (United States)">Libertarian Party</a> as its presidential nominee on May 26, 2024, at the <a href="/wiki/2024_Libertarian_National_Convention" title="2024 Libertarian National Convention">2024 Libertarian National Convention</a>. Oliver was the party's nominee in the <a href="/wiki/2022_United_States_Senate_election_in_Georgia" title="2022 United States Senate election in Georgia">2022 United States Senate election in Georgia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>188<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Oliver achieved <a href="/wiki/Ballot_access_in_the_2024_United_States_presidential_election" title="Ballot access in the 2024 United States presidential election">ballot access</a> in 47 states, and was eligible to receive write-in votes in the District of Columbia, Illinois, New York, and Tennessee.<sup id="cite_ref-TGP_ballot_access_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TGP_ballot_access-190"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>189<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NY_write-in_191-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NY_write-in-191"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>190<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; text-align:center">

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading5"><h5 id="Green_Party">Green Party</h5></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1129693374"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1246091330"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1157919884"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1239334494"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1214851843"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1214851843"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1214851843"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1214851843"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1214851843"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1214851843"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1214851843"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1214851843"><table class="sidebar nomobile nowraplinks sidebar-person vcard hlist"><tbody><tr><th class="sidebar-title"><table><tbody><tr>

<hr></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1129693374"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1239400231"><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Jill_Stein_series" title="Template:Jill Stein series"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Jill_Stein_series" title="Template talk:Jill Stein series"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a href="/wiki/Special:EditPage/Template:Jill_Stein_series" title="Special:EditPage/Template:Jill Stein series"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/2024_Green_Party_presidential_primaries" title="2024 Green Party presidential primaries">2024 Green Party presidential primaries</a>, <a href="/wiki/2024_Green_National_Convention" title="2024 Green National Convention">2024 Green National Convention</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jill_Stein_2024_presidential_campaign" title="Jill Stein 2024 presidential campaign">Jill Stein 2024 presidential campaign</a></div>
<p>The party's nominee in <a href="/wiki/Jill_Stein_2012_presidential_campaign" title="Jill Stein 2012 presidential campaign">2012</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jill_Stein_2016_presidential_campaign" title="Jill Stein 2016 presidential campaign">2016</a>, Stein is a physician and a former member of the <a href="/wiki/Lexington,_Massachusetts" title="Lexington, Massachusetts">Lexington</a> <a href="/wiki/Representative_town_meeting" title="Representative town meeting">Town Meeting</a>. On August 16, Stein selected academic <a href="/wiki/Butch_Ware" title="Butch Ware">Butch Ware</a> as her running mate.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>191<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Stein achieved ballot access in 38 states, and was eligible to receive write-in votes in seven states. She was not eligible to receive write-in votes in the remaining states or the District of Columbia.<sup id="cite_ref-TGP_ballot_access_190-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TGP_ballot_access-190"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>189<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ballotpedia_write-in_193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ballotpedia_write-in-193"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>192<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NY_write-in_191-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NY_write-in-191"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>190<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; text-align:center">

</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="width:16em">Physician<br>from <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts" title="Massachusetts">Massachusetts</a>
</td>
<td style="width:16em">Academic<br>from <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th colspan="2"><figure class="mw-halign-center" typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:SteinWare.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/SteinWare.png/250px-SteinWare.png" decoding="async" width="148" height="112" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/SteinWare.png/330px-SteinWare.png 2x" data-file-width="786" data-file-height="594"></a><figcaption></figcaption></figure>
</th></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="With_partial_ballot_access">With partial ballot access</h4></div>
<p>These third-party candidates had ballot access in some states, but not enough to get 270 votes needed to win the presidency, without running a <a href="/wiki/Write-in_candidate" title="Write-in candidate">write-in campaign</a>.
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/American_Solidarity_Party" title="American Solidarity Party">American Solidarity Party</a>: <a href="/wiki/Peter_Sonski" title="Peter Sonski">Peter Sonski</a>, Connecticut school board member<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>193<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Approval_Voting_Party" title="Approval Voting Party">Approval Voting Party</a>: Blake Huber, activist and nominee for president in 2020<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>194<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Constitution_Party_(United_States)" title="Constitution Party (United States)">Constitution Party</a>: <a href="/wiki/Randall_Terry" title="Randall Terry">Randall Terry</a>, anti-abortion activist and <a href="/wiki/Perennial_candidate" title="Perennial candidate">perennial candidate</a><sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>195<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Independent_American_Party_of_Nevada" title="Independent American Party of Nevada">Independent American Party</a>: <a href="/wiki/Joel_Skousen" title="Joel Skousen">Joel Skousen</a>, survivalist and consultant<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>196<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Natural_Law_Party_(United_States)" title="Natural Law Party (United States)">Natural Law Party</a>: <a href="/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy_Jr." title="Robert F. Kennedy Jr.">Robert F. Kennedy Jr.</a>, environmental lawyer and author, the party's nominee in addition to his run as an independent before he <a href="#Withdrawn_candidates">withdrew</a> from the race ahead of the election but was not removed from ballots<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>197<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Prohibition_Party" title="Prohibition Party">Prohibition Party</a>: Michael Wood, businessman<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>198<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Party_for_Socialism_and_Liberation" title="Party for Socialism and Liberation">Party for Socialism and Liberation</a>: <a href="/wiki/Claudia_De_la_Cruz" title="Claudia De la Cruz">Claudia De la Cruz</a>, political activist<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>199<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>200<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Socialist_Equality_Party_(United_States)" title="Socialist Equality Party (United States)">Socialist Equality Party</a>: <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Kishore" title="Joseph Kishore">Joseph Kishore</a>, writer and SEP nominee in 2020<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>201<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Socialist_Workers_Party_(United_States)" title="Socialist Workers Party (United States)">Socialist Workers Party</a>: <a href="/wiki/Rachele_Fruit" title="Rachele Fruit">Rachele Fruit</a>, hotel worker and trade unionist<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>202<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Socialist_Party_USA" title="Socialist Party USA">Socialist Party USA</a>: Bill Stodden, nonprofit executive<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>203<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li></ul>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Independent_candidates">Independent candidates</h4></div>
<p>The following notable individual(s) ran independently for president.
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Cornel_West" title="Cornel West">Cornel West</a>, academic, anti-war activist, and public intellectual, previously a <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Party_(United_States,_2017)" title="People's Party (United States, 2017)">People's Party</a> and <a href="/wiki/2024_Green_Party_presidential_primaries" title="2024 Green Party presidential primaries">Green Party primaries</a> candidate,<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>204<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>205<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> who launched <a href="/wiki/Cornel_West_2024_presidential_campaign" title="Cornel West 2024 presidential campaign">an independent campaign</a><sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>206<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li></ul>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Withdrawn_candidates_3">Withdrawn candidates</h4></div>
<p>The following notable individual(s) announced and then suspended their campaigns before the election:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy_Jr." title="Robert F. Kennedy Jr.">Robert F. Kennedy Jr.</a>, environmental lawyer, author, <a href="/wiki/2024_Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries" title="2024 Democratic Party presidential primaries">2024 Democratic presidential candidate</a> and <a href="/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy_Jr._2024_presidential_campaign" title="Robert F. Kennedy Jr. 2024 presidential campaign">2024 independent presidential candidate</a> <i>(endorsed Trump)</i><sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>208<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li></ul>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Campaign_issues">Campaign issues</h2></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Campaign_themes">Campaign themes</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Kamala_Harris_2024_presidential_campaign#Platform" title="Kamala Harris 2024 presidential campaign">Kamala Harris 2024 presidential campaign &nbsp;Platform</a>, <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_2024_presidential_campaign#Platform" title="Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign">Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign &nbsp;Platform</a>, and <a href="/wiki/2024_United_States_elections#Issues" title="2024 United States elections">2024 United States elections &nbsp;Issues</a></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Harris_campaign">Harris campaign</h4></div>
<p>Harris framed her campaign as "a choice between freedom and chaos" and based it around the ideals of "freedom" and "the future".<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>209<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>210<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Harris campaign sought to highlight her experience as an attorney general and a prosecutor to "prosecute the case" against Trump by pointing out his 34 felony convictions and the impacts of the overturning of <i><a href="/wiki/Roe_v._Wade" title="Roe v. Wade">Roe v. Wade</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>211<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>212<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris had taken liberal positions on a number of issues in her bid for the 2020 Democratic nomination; in 2024, she shifted several of those positions toward the political center and embraced many of Biden's domestic policy stances.<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-7_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-7-214"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>213<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris focused her economic proposals on the cost of <a href="/wiki/Grocery_prices_(greedflation)" class="mw-redirect" title="Grocery prices (greedflation)">groceries</a>, <a href="/wiki/Housing_crisis_in_the_United_States" title="Housing crisis in the United States">housing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Health_care_prices_in_the_United_States" title="Health care prices in the United States">healthcare</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>214<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Trump_campaign">Trump campaign</h4></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Trumpism" title="Trumpism">Trumpism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rhetoric_of_Donald_Trump" title="Rhetoric of Donald Trump">Rhetoric of Donald Trump</a></div>
<p>A central campaign theme for Trump's second presidential bid was "<a href="/wiki/Revenge" title="Revenge">retribution</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>215<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>216<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump framed the 2024 election as "the final battle", and openly promised to leverage the power of the presidency for <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_2024_presidential_campaign#Investigation_and_arrest_of_political_rivals" title="Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign">political reprisals</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>217<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump heavily ran on immigration as a central campaign focus. Trump's campaign focused on dark and apocalyptic rhetoric about the state of the country and predicting doom if he did not win.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>218<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>219<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Parker_03172024_221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Parker_03172024-221"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>220<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Associated_Press" title="Associated Press">Associated Press</a> stated that "Trump's rallies take on the symbols, rhetoric and agenda of <a href="/wiki/Christian_nationalism_in_the_United_States" title="Christian nationalism in the United States">Christian nationalism</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>221<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> During his 2024 presidential campaign, Trump made numerous <a href="/wiki/False_or_misleading_statements_by_Donald_Trump#Campaign_for_2024_presidency" title="False or misleading statements by Donald Trump">false and misleading statements</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Los_Angeles_Times-2024_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Los_Angeles_Times-2024-223"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_Washington_Post-2024-2_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Washington_Post-2024-2-224"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>223<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_Washington_Post-2024_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Washington_Post-2024-225"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>224<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump has been described as using the "<a href="/wiki/Big_lie" title="Big lie">big lie</a>"<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>225<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Firehose_of_falsehood" title="Firehose of falsehood">firehose of falsehood</a><sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>226<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> propaganda techniques.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Abortion">Abortion</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Abortion_in_the_United_States" title="Abortion in the United States">Abortion in the United States</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Pro-ChoiceMarch_3792_(52075189799).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Pro-ChoiceMarch_3792_%2852075189799%29.jpg/250px-Pro-ChoiceMarch_3792_%2852075189799%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Pro-ChoiceMarch_3792_%2852075189799%29.jpg/500px-Pro-ChoiceMarch_3792_%2852075189799%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="6000" data-file-height="4000"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/United_States_abortion-rights_movement" title="United States abortion-rights movement">Abortion-rights</a> protesters in <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> in May 2022, as part of the Bans Off Our Bodies protest following the <a href="/wiki/Leaked_draft_opinion_in_Dobbs_v._Jackson_Women%27s_Health_Organization" class="mw-redirect" title="Leaked draft opinion in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization">leaked draft opinion</a> overturning <i><a href="/wiki/Roe_v._Wade" title="Roe v. Wade">Roe v. Wade</a></i></figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:March_for_Life_(49435740948).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/March_for_Life_%2849435740948%29.jpg/250px-March_for_Life_%2849435740948%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/March_for_Life_%2849435740948%29.jpg/500px-March_for_Life_%2849435740948%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3500" data-file-height="2333"></a><figcaption>Trump speaking at the 2020 <a href="/wiki/March_for_Life_(Washington,_D.C.)" title="March for Life (Washington, D.C.)">March for Life</a> in Washington, D.C.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/Abortion" title="Abortion">Abortion</a> access was a key topic during the campaign;<sup id="cite_ref-heres-why-abortion_228-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-heres-why-abortion-228"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>227<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NBC-2024_229-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NBC-2024-229"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>228<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> it was on the ballot in up to ten states in 2024, including the swing states of <a href="/wiki/2024_Arizona_Proposition_139" title="2024 Arizona Proposition 139">Arizona</a> and Nevada.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>229<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Some pundits argued abortion-rights referendums could help Harris in November.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>230<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>231<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>232<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Democrats predominantly advocate for <a href="/wiki/United_States_abortion-rights_movement" title="United States abortion-rights movement">abortion access as a right</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>233<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> while Republicans generally favor significantly <a href="/wiki/United_States_anti-abortion_movement" title="United States anti-abortion movement">restricting the legality of abortion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>234<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Since becoming the presumptive nominee, Harris indicated her support for passing legislation which would restore the federal abortion right protections previously guaranteed by <i>Roe</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>235<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-3_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-3-237"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> She argued Trump would let his anti-abortion allies implement <a href="/wiki/Project_2025_and_women%27s_reproductive_health" class="mw-redirect" title="Project 2025 and women's reproductive health">Project 2025 proposals</a> to restrict abortion and contraception throughout the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>237<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Trump claimed credit for overturning <i>Roe</i> but criticized Republicans pushing for total abortion bans.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>238<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>239<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump said he would leave the issue of abortion for the states to decide but would allow red states to monitor women's pregnancies and prosecute them if they have an abortion.<sup id="cite_ref-Time-2024_241-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Time-2024-241"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>240<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In his home state of Florida, Trump announced he would vote "No" on <a href="/wiki/2024_Florida_Amendment_4" title="2024 Florida Amendment 4">Amendment 4</a>, an abortion rights referendum, preserving the six-week ban.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>241<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The announcement came one day after he initially criticized the six-week ban for being "too short" and said he would vote to lengthen it.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>242<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump repeated a false claim that Democrats support abortions after birth and "executing" babies.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>243<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>244<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Border_security_and_immigration">Border security and immigration</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_border_crisis" title="MexicoUnited States border crisis">MexicoUnited States border crisis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Border_security_in_the_United_States" title="Border security in the United States">Border security in the United States</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Kamala_Harris_2024_presidential_campaign#Immigration" title="Kamala Harris 2024 presidential campaign">Kamala Harris 2024 presidential campaign &nbsp;Immigration</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_2024_presidential_campaign#Immigration" title="Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign">Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign &nbsp;Immigration</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Attorney_General_Harris_Tours_U.S.-Mexico_Border_N2063_border_1.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Attorney_General_Harris_Tours_U.S.-Mexico_Border_N2063_border_1.jpg/250px-Attorney_General_Harris_Tours_U.S.-Mexico_Border_N2063_border_1.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Attorney_General_Harris_Tours_U.S.-Mexico_Border_N2063_border_1.jpg/500px-Attorney_General_Harris_Tours_U.S.-Mexico_Border_N2063_border_1.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1365"></a><figcaption>Harris as <a href="/wiki/Attorney_General_of_California" title="Attorney General of California">Attorney General of California</a> at the border in 2011 to discuss strategies to combat transnational gang crime</figcaption></figure>
<p>Border security and immigration were among the top issues concerning potential voters in the election.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>245<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-democracy-2024-election_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-democracy-2024-election-247"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>246<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Polling showed that most Americans want to reduce immigration,<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>247<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and that a substantial minority of white Republicans were concerned about <a href="/wiki/White_demographic_decline" title="White demographic decline">White demographic decline</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>248<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2023 and early 2024, a surge of migrants entering through the border with Mexico occurred.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>249<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> By June 2024, illegal crossings reached a three-year low following four consecutive monthly drops, which senior officials attributed to increased enforcement between the United States and Mexico, the weather, and Biden's executive order (<a href="/wiki/A_Proclamation_on_Securing_the_Border" title="A Proclamation on Securing the Border">A Proclamation on Securing the Border</a>) increasing asylum restrictions.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>250<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Harris promised to fight for "strong border security" coupled with an earned pathway to citizenship. Harris highlighted her work in combating transnational gangs, drug cartels, and human traffickers while attorney general.<sup id="cite_ref-Politico-2024_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Politico-2024-252"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>251<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As vice president, Harris announced in 2023 that she had garnered pledges of US$950&nbsp;million from private companies to aid Central American communities to address the causes of mass migration, such as poverty.<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-3_237-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-3-237"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris stated she believes the immigration system is "broken" and needs to be fixed, and she said most Americans believe this.<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-3_237-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-3-237"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris also advocated for stricter asylum rules than President Biden.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>252<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris supported increasing the number of <a href="/wiki/U.S._Border_Patrol" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Border Patrol">U.S. Border Patrol</a> agents and accused Trump of being unserious on border security.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>253<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As vice president, Harris also supported a bipartisan bill that would have funded additional border agents and closed the border if too crowded; the bill was rejected by Trump. Trump called on House and Senate Republicans to kill the bill arguing it would hurt his and Republican's reelection campaigns and deny them the ability to run on immigration as a campaign issue.<sup id="cite_ref-trump-border-biden_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-trump-border-biden-255"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>254<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>255<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>256<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>257<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>258<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>259<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris criticized Trump for his opposition to the bill on the campaign trail,<sup id="cite_ref-Politico-2024_252-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Politico-2024-252"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>251<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and promised to sign the bill into law as president.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>260<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:President_Trump_Travels_to_Arizona_(50040937841).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/President_Trump_Travels_to_Arizona_%2850040937841%29.jpg/250px-President_Trump_Travels_to_Arizona_%2850040937841%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/President_Trump_Travels_to_Arizona_%2850040937841%29.jpg/500px-President_Trump_Travels_to_Arizona_%2850040937841%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2800" data-file-height="1867"></a><figcaption>Trump pledged to finish <a href="/wiki/Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_border_wall" title="MexicoUnited States border wall">the wall</a> on the southern border if elected.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Trump stated that if he were elected, he would increase deportations, send the U.S. military to the border, expand <a href="/wiki/U.S._Immigration_and_Customs_Enforcement" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement">U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement</a> detentions through workplace raids,<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2023-3_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2023-3-262"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>261<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> deputize local law enforcement to handle border security, increase <a href="/wiki/U.S._Customs_and_Border_Patrol" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Customs and Border Patrol">U.S. Customs and Border Patrol</a> funding, as well as finish building the wall on the southern border.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>262<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump has said he will deport both legal and illegal immigrants.<sup id="cite_ref-Oliphant_10042024_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oliphant_10042024-11"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>263<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i>The New York Times</i> reported that Trump was considering "an extreme expansion of his first-term crackdown on immigration", such as "preparing to round up undocumented people already in the United States on a vast scale and detain them in sprawling camps while they wait to be expelled".<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2023-3_262-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2023-3-262"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>261<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump stated his intention to deport 11 million people through the construction of detention camps and deploy the military,<sup id="cite_ref-Time-2024_241-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Time-2024-241"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>240<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> relying on presidential wartime powers under the 18th-century <a href="/wiki/Alien_Enemies_Act" class="mw-redirect" title="Alien Enemies Act">Alien Enemies Act</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ward_10122024_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ward_10122024-265"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>264<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump made false claims of a "migrant crime wave" that are not supported by data, and provided no evidence to back up his claims.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>265<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Reid_09292024_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reid_09292024-267"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>266<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In regards to his anti-immigrant <a href="/wiki/Nativism_(politics)" title="Nativism (politics)">nativism</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Bender_09252024_268-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bender_09252024-268"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>267<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump's tone grew harsher from his previous time as president,<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2023-3_262-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2023-3-262"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>261<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and used <a href="/wiki/Fearmongering" title="Fearmongering">fearmongering</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>268<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>269<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> racial stereotypes,<sup id="cite_ref-Bender_09252024_268-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bender_09252024-268"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>267<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and more dehumanizing rhetoric when referring to illegal immigrants. Trump repeatedly called some immigrants subhuman, stating they are "not human", "not people", and "animals",<sup id="cite_ref-Reuters-2024-2_271-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters-2024-2-271"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>270<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>271<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>272<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> who will "rape, pillage, thieve, plunder and kill" American citizens,<sup id="cite_ref-Oliphant_10042024_11-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oliphant_10042024-11"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> that they are "stone-cold killers", "monsters", "vile animals", "savages", and "predators" that will "walk into your kitchen, they'll cut your throat",<sup id="cite_ref-Gold_1012024_274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gold_1012024-274"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>273<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hutzler_09302024_275-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hutzler_09302024-275"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>274<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Oliphant_10042024_11-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oliphant_10042024-11"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Reid_09292024_267-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reid_09292024-267"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>266<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and "grab young girls and slice them up right in front of their parents".<sup id="cite_ref-Oliphant_10042024_11-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oliphant_10042024-11"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Other rhetoric includes false statements that foreign leaders are deliberately emptying insane asylums to send "prisoners, murderers, drug dealers, mental patients, terrorists" across the southern border as migrants,<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>275<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> that they are "building an army" of "fighting age" men to attack Americans "from within",<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>276<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and are the "enemy from within" who are ruining the "fabric" of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-Ward_10122024_265-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ward_10122024-265"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>264<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Since fall 2023,<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-5_278-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-5-278"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump claimed that immigrants are "poisoning the blood of our country", which drew comparisons to <a href="/wiki/Racial_hygiene" title="Racial hygiene">racial hygiene</a> rhetoric used by <a href="/wiki/White_supremacists" class="mw-redirect" title="White supremacists">White supremacists</a> and <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Hitler" title="Adolf Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>278<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>279<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-5_278-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-5-278"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2023-5_281-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2023-5-281"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>280<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the 20 rallies that occurred after <a href="/wiki/Trump%27s_debate_with_Harris" class="mw-redirect" title="Trump's debate with Harris">Trump's debate with Harris</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Politico" title="Politico">Politico</a></i> cited experts who found that Trump's rhetoric strongly echoed authoritarian and <a href="/wiki/Nazi_ideology" class="mw-redirect" title="Nazi ideology">Nazi ideology</a>; Trump made claims that immigrants are genetically predisposed to commit crimes and have "bad genes".<sup id="cite_ref-Ward_10122024_265-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ward_10122024-265"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>264<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Bad_Genes_282-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bad_Genes-282"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>281<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Climate_change">Climate change</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_the_United_States" title="Climate change in the United States">Climate change in the United States</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Kamala_Harris_2024_presidential_campaign#Climate_change_and_energy" title="Kamala Harris 2024 presidential campaign">Kamala Harris 2024 presidential campaign &nbsp;Climate change and energy</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_2024_presidential_campaign#Energy,_environment,_and_climate_change" title="Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign">Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign &nbsp;Energy, environment, and climate change</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Environmental_policy_of_the_first_Donald_Trump_administration" title="Environmental policy of the first Donald Trump administration">Environmental policy of the first Donald Trump administration</a>, <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_denial" title="Climate change denial">Climate change denial</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Inflation_Reduction_Act" title="Inflation Reduction Act">Inflation Reduction Act</a></div>
<p>Climate change and energy policy played a role in the 2024 presidential campaign. In 2023, the United States saw a record in crude oil production with over 13.2&nbsp;million barrels of crude per day, beating the 13 million barrels per day produced at the peak of Trump's presidency.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>282<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The United States also dealt with supply shocks caused by the <a href="/wiki/2021%E2%80%932024_global_energy_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="20212024 global energy crisis">20212024 global energy crisis</a> due to the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="Russian invasion of Ukraine">Russian invasion of Ukraine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>283<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> An advocate for <a href="/wiki/Environmental_justice" title="Environmental justice">environmental justice</a> to address the impact of climate change on lower-income areas and people of color, Harris supported Biden's climate legislation.<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-3_237-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-3-237"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2022, Harris helped pass the Inflation Reduction Act,<sup id="cite_ref-The_Hill-2024_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Hill-2024-285"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>284<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> the largest investment in addressing climate change and clean energy in American history,<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>285<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> putting the United States on track to meet emissions reduction targets by 5052% below 2005 levels by 2030.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>286<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris's campaign stated that she would not support a ban on <a href="/wiki/Fracking" title="Fracking">fracking</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-7_214-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-7-214"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>213<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Trump ridiculed the idea of man-made <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>287<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>288<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>289<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and repeatedly referred to his energy policy under the mantra "<a href="/wiki/Drill,_baby,_drill" title="Drill, baby, drill">drill, baby, drill</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>290<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump said he would increase oil drilling on public lands and offer tax breaks to oil, gas, and coal producers, and stated his goal for the United States to have the lowest cost of electricity and energy of any country in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-AP_Trump_Plans_292-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AP_Trump_Plans-292"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump also promised to roll back electric vehicle initiatives, proposed once again the <a href="/wiki/United_States_withdrawal_from_the_Paris_Agreement" class="mw-redirect" title="United States withdrawal from the Paris Agreement">United States withdrawal from the Paris Agreement</a>, and rescind several environmental regulations.<sup id="cite_ref-AP_Trump_Plans_292-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AP_Trump_Plans-292"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>292<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump stated his intention to roll back parts of the Inflation Reduction Act.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>293<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The implementation of Trump's plans would add around 4&nbsp;billion tons of <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide">carbon dioxide</a> to the atmosphere by 2030, also having effects on the international level. If the policies do not change further, it would add 15&nbsp;billion tons by 2040 and 27&nbsp;billion by 2050. Although the exact calculation is difficult, researchers stated: "Regardless of the precise impact, a second Trump term that successfully dismantles <a href="/wiki/Environmental_policy_of_the_Joe_Biden_administration" title="Environmental policy of the Joe Biden administration">Biden's climate legacy</a> would likely end any global hopes of keeping global warming below 1.5C."<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>294<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Democracy">Democracy</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Attempts_to_overturn_the_2020_United_States_presidential_election" title="Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election">Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election</a>, <a href="/wiki/Democratic_backsliding_in_the_United_States" title="Democratic backsliding in the United States">Democratic backsliding in the United States</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Election_denial_movement_in_the_United_States" title="Election denial movement in the United States">Election denial movement in the United States</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_2024_presidential_campaign#Authoritarian_and_antidemocratic_statements" title="Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign">Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign &nbsp;Authoritarian and antidemocratic statements</a>, <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_and_fascism" title="Donald Trump and fascism">Donald Trump and fascism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indictments_against_Donald_Trump" title="Indictments against Donald Trump">Indictments against Donald Trump</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Project_2025" title="Project 2025">Project 2025</a></div>

href="/wiki/File:2021_storming_of_the_United_States_Capitol_DSC09156_collage.png" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/2021_storming_of_the_United_States_Capitol_DSC09156_collage.png/250px-2021_storming_of_the_United_States_Capitol_DSC09156_collage.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="234" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/2021_storming_of_the_United_States_Capitol_DSC09156_collage.png/330px-2021_storming_of_the_United_States_Capitol_DSC09156_collage.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/2021_storming_of_the_United_States_Capitol_DSC09156_collage.png/500px-2021_storming_of_the_United_States_Capitol_DSC09156_collage.png 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1868"></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">The election was the first presidential election following Trump's <a href="/wiki/Attempts_to_overturn_the_2020_election" class="mw-redirect" title="Attempts to overturn the 2020 election">attempts to overturn the 2020 election</a> and the <a href="/wiki/January_6_United_States_Capitol_attack" title="January 6 United States Capitol attack">January 6 United States Capitol attack</a>. It also came amidst <a href="/wiki/Federal_prosecution_of_Donald_Trump_(election_obstruction_case)" title="Federal prosecution of Donald Trump (election obstruction case)">Trump's federal indictment</a> for attempting to overturn the 2020 election and involvement in the attack and <a href="/wiki/Georgia_election_racketeering_prosecution" title="Georgia election racketeering prosecution">racketeering charges for attempting to overturn Biden's victory in Georgia</a>.</div></div></div></div>
<p>Polling before the election indicated profound dissatisfaction with the state of <a href="/wiki/American_democracy" class="mw-redirect" title="American democracy">American democracy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>295<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>296<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>297<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> According to an October 25 ABC/Ipsos poll, 49% of Americans saw Trump as a <a href="/wiki/Fascist" class="mw-redirect" title="Fascist">fascist</a>, described as "a political extremist who seeks to act as a dictator, disregards individual rights and threatens or uses force against their opponents". Meanwhile, only 22% saw Harris as a fascist by this definition.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>298<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Some Republicans were concerned that Trump's former <a href="/wiki/Second_impeachment_trial_of_Donald_Trump" title="Second impeachment trial of Donald Trump">impeachment</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indictments_against_Donald_Trump" title="Indictments against Donald Trump">four criminal indictments</a> were attempts to influence the election and keep him from office;<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>299<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> however, there is no evidence that Trump's criminal trials were "election interference" orchestrated by Biden and the Democratic Party,<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-6_20-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-6-20"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>19<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-4_74-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-4-74"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>73<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and Trump also continued to repeat <a href="/wiki/False_claims_of_fraud_in_the_2020_United_States_presidential_election" class="mw-redirect" title="False claims of fraud in the 2020 United States presidential election">false claims</a> that the 2020 election was rigged and stolen from him.<sup id="cite_ref-Associated_Press-2023-2_301-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Associated_Press-2023-2-301"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>300<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Trump's 2024 presidential campaign was criticized by legal experts, historians, and political scientists for making increasingly <a href="/wiki/Dehumanizing" class="mw-redirect" title="Dehumanizing">dehumanizing</a>, violent, and <a href="/wiki/Authoritarian" class="mw-redirect" title="Authoritarian">authoritarian</a> statements.<sup id="cite_ref-Associated_Press-2023-4_302-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Associated_Press-2023-4-302"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>301<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2023-2_303-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2023-2-303"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>302<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_Guardian-2023_304-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Guardian-2023-304"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>303<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump's platform called for the vast expansion of presidential powers and the executive branch over every part of the federal government.<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>304<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump called for stripping employment protections for thousands of career civil service employees (a provision known as <a href="/wiki/Schedule_F_appointment" title="Schedule F appointment">Schedule F appointment</a> that had been adopted by Trump at the end of 2020) and replacing them with political loyalists if deemed an "obstacle to his agenda" within federal agencies, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Intelligence_Community" title="United States Intelligence Community">United States Intelligence Community</a>, <a href="/wiki/State_Department" class="mw-redirect" title="State Department">State Department</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Defense" class="mw-redirect" title="Department of Defense">Department of Defense</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>305<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump repeatedly stated his intention to have the Justice Department investigate and arrest his domestic political rivals, judges, prosecutors, and witnesses involved in his criminal trials.<sup id="cite_ref-vows_114-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vows-114"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>113<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>306<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NYMag_Never_Sounded_Like_This_308-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYMag_Never_Sounded_Like_This-308"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>307<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Calling the <a href="/wiki/January_6,_2021,_Capitol_attack" class="mw-redirect" title="January 6, 2021, Capitol attack">January 6, 2021, Capitol attack</a> a "day of love", Trump promised to <a href="/wiki/Criminal_proceedings_in_the_January_6_United_States_Capitol_attack#Trump's_consideration_of_presidential_pardon" title="Criminal proceedings in the January 6 United States Capitol attack">pardon those charged for their involvement</a> and called them "hostages" and "great, great patriots".<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>308<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>309<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>310<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>311<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump played down the possibility of violence if he were to lose the 2024 election, but did not rule it out altogether.<sup id="cite_ref-IbssaKim2024_115-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IbssaKim2024-115"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>114<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Trump's 2024 campaign rhetoric has been described as fascist.<sup id="cite_ref-Vox_Fascist_313-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vox_Fascist-313"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>312<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-New_Yorker_Fascist_314-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-New_Yorker_Fascist-314"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>313<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_Atlantic_Fascist_315-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Atlantic_Fascist-315"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>314<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump said his political opponents are a greater threat to the United States than countries such as Russia, China, and North Korea.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Washington_Post-2023_316-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Washington_Post-2023-316"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>315<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>316<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> He urged
