that the U.S. Armed Forces be deployed on American soil to fight "the enemy from within", whichaccording to Trumpincluded "radical left lunatics" and Democratic politicians such as <a href="/wiki/Adam_Schiff" title="Adam Schiff">Adam Schiff</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>317<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump repeatedly voiced support for outlawing political dissent and criticism he considers misleading or challenges his claims to power.<sup id="cite_ref-Blake_09242024_319-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Blake_09242024-319"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>318<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Kapur_10132024_320-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kapur_10132024-320"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>319<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump previously tried to have his political rivals prosecuted during his first term.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>320<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Harris was tasked by Biden with protecting democracy through voting rights legislation through her work on the <a href="/wiki/For_the_People_Act" title="For the People Act">For the People Act</a>. Harris supported efforts to defend election workers and counter <a href="/wiki/Republican_efforts_to_restrict_voting_following_the_2020_presidential_election" class="mw-redirect" title="Republican efforts to restrict voting following the 2020 presidential election">Republican efforts to restrict voting following the 2020 presidential election</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-3_237-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-3-237"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris also stated her intent to pass the <a href="/wiki/Freedom_to_Vote_Act" class="mw-redirect" title="Freedom to Vote Act">Freedom to Vote Act</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Lewis_Rights_Voting_Rights_Advancement_Act" class="mw-redirect" title="John Lewis Rights Voting Rights Advancement Act">John Lewis Rights Voting Rights Advancement Act</a> if elected.<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>321<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Economic_issues">Economic issues</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_United_States" title="Economy of the United States">Economy of the United States</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Kamala_Harris_2024_presidential_campaign#Economy" title="Kamala Harris 2024 presidential campaign">Kamala Harris 2024 presidential campaign &nbsp;Economy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_2024_presidential_campaign#Economy_and_trade" title="Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign">Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign &nbsp;Economy and trade</a>, and <a href="/wiki/U.S._federal_government_response_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic" title="U.S. federal government response to the COVID-19 pandemic">U.S. federal government response to the COVID-19 pandemic</a></div>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Inflation_2018-2024_US_vs._EuroZone.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Inflation_2018-2024_US_vs._EuroZone.png/250px-Inflation_2018-2024_US_vs._EuroZone.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="111" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Inflation_2018-2024_US_vs._EuroZone.png/330px-Inflation_2018-2024_US_vs._EuroZone.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Inflation_2018-2024_US_vs._EuroZone.png/500px-Inflation_2018-2024_US_vs._EuroZone.png 2x" data-file-width="1238" data-file-height="684"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/2021%E2%80%932023_inflation_surge_in_the_United_States" class="mw-redirect" title="20212023 inflation surge in the United States">Post-COVID inflation spike in the United States</a>, with the gray column indicating the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_recession_in_the_United_States" class="mw-redirect" title="COVID-19 recession in the United States">COVID-19 recession</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Voters consistently cited the economy as their top issue in the 2024 election.<sup id="cite_ref-Pew_Research_Center_2024_323-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pew_Research_Center_2024-323"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>322<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Following the COVID-19 pandemic, <a href="/wiki/2021%E2%80%932023_inflation_surge" title="20212023 inflation surge">a global surge in inflation</a> ensued that raised prices on many goods, although the U.S. inflation rate had declined significantly during 2023 and 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>323<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>324<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>325<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i>The New York Times</i> reported that both candidates "embraced a vision of a powerful federal government, using its muscle to intervene in markets in pursuit of a stronger and more prosperous economy".<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-8_327-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-8-327"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>326<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i> reported that economists found Trump's proposed policies created a greater risk of stoking inflation and generating higher budget deficits, relative to the Harris plan.<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>327<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Twenty-three Nobel Prize-winning economists signed a letter characterizing the Harris economic plan as "vastly superior" to the Trump plan.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>328<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump's designated government efficiency leader <a href="/wiki/Elon_Musk" title="Elon Musk">Elon Musk</a> said in October that he expected Trump's plan would involve more than $2&nbsp;trillion in federal spending cuts and would cause "some temporary hardship."<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>329<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>330<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris ran on a pro-union platform.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>331<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> She promoted the passage of the <a href="/wiki/Infrastructure_Investment_and_Jobs_Act" title="Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act">Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act</a>, funding for small business, and previously supported an act as senator to provide a $6,000 tax credit for middle and low-income families.<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-3_237-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-3-237"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris promised to address <a href="/wiki/Price_gouging" title="Price gouging">price gouging</a>, bring down costs, ban hidden fees and late charges from financial institutions, limit "unfair" rent increases and cap prescription drug costs, which she said would "lower costs and save many middle-class families thousands of dollars a year".<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>332<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><i>The New York Times</i> described Harris's economic policy as embracing "the idea that the federal government must act aggressively to foster competition and correct distortions in private markets". Harris proposed raising taxes on corporations and high-earners to fund services for the lower and middle classes and reduce the deficit.<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-8_327-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-8-327"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>326<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris stated she supported increasing the top tier capital gains tax rate to 28%, up from 20% and lower than Biden's proposed 39.6%. Harris stated her support for a Billionaire Minimum Income Tax, increasing the tax on stock buybacks to 4%, and a ten-fold tax reduction for small business ranging from $5,000 to $50,000 in relief.<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>333<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris also supported efforts to create a tax on unrealized gains for those with more than a $100&nbsp;million in net worth if they do not pay a minimum 25% tax rate on their income inclusive of unrealized gains so long as 80% of said wealth is in tradeable assets. The plan would impact a small percentage of the wealthy in the United States, and <i><a href="/wiki/Axios_(website)" title="Axios (website)">Axios</a></i> reported most tech founders and investors would be spared.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>334<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris also announced support for restoring the corporate tax rate to 28% among several other tax proposals to raise taxes and close loopholes for corporations and the wealthy that would bring in $5&nbsp;trillion in additional revenue over 10 years.<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>335<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris proposed tax breaks to companies delivering economic benefit, such as manufacturing technologies that <a href="/wiki/Mitigate_climate_change" class="mw-redirect" title="Mitigate climate change">mitigate climate change</a> and building <a href="/wiki/Affordable_housing" title="Affordable housing">affordable housing</a>, and proposed a ban on corporate price gouging to "help the food industry become more competitive".<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-8_327-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-8-327"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>326<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris also expressed support for student debt relief,<sup id="cite_ref-CNN-2024-2_337-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNN-2024-2-337"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>336<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and said she supported raising the <a href="/wiki/Minimum_wage_in_the_United_States" title="Minimum wage in the United States">minimum wage</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nytaug11_338-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytaug11-338"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>337<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In response to the <a href="/wiki/Housing_crisis_in_the_United_States" title="Housing crisis in the United States">housing crisis in the United States</a>, Harris said she would increase home construction to reduce housing costs, arguing that it negatively impacts the economy and hurts working-class families. Harris proposed directing $40&nbsp;billion to construction companies to build starter homes, and promised to send $25,000 in down-payment assistance to every first time home buyer.<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-8_327-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-8-327"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>326<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris said she would urge Congress to enforce fair housing laws and pass a bill to bar property owners from using services that "coordinate" rents through the passage of the Preventing the Algorithmic Facilitation of Rental Housing Cartels Act, and also call on Congress to pass the Stop Predatory Investing Act by removing tax benefits to Wall Street firms that buy up large numbers of single-family homes.<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>338<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>339<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump proposed further individual and corporate tax cuts beyond the <a href="/wiki/2017_Tax_Cuts_and_Jobs_Act" class="mw-redirect" title="2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act">2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>340<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump argued that keeping taxes low for the wealthy increases job creation,<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>341<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and that these policies coupled with a crackdown in illegal immigration and reduction in inflation would help the middle class.<sup id="cite_ref-CNN-2024-2_337-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNN-2024-2-337"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>336<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump said he would reduce regulation of business through the creation of an efficiency commission led by Musk,<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>342<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> along with reducing environmental regulation. By October 2024, Musk was Trump's second-largest individual campaign donor.<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>343<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump said deporting millions of immigrants would bring housing prices down, although most economists argue it could raise prices by removing construction workers who use less real estate.<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-8_327-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-8-327"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>326<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>344<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump and Harris support not taxing tips for at least hospitality and service workers.<sup id="cite_ref-nytaug11_338-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytaug11-338"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>337<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>345<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump suggested that he would abolish the federal income tax and replace it with tariffs. In June 2024, Trump discussed the idea of eliminating the income tax in a private meeting with Republican politicians.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>346<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In October 2024, Trump suggested that he would scrap the income tax if he wins, pointing out that tariffs were the main sources of revenue in the 19th century.<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>347<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Trump's stated trade policy involves the United States decoupling from the global economy and having the country become more self-contained and exerting its power through individual trade dealings. This would be attempted largely through a universal baseline tariff,<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2023-6_349-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2023-6-349"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>348<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> set from 10% to 20% on all imports,<sup id="cite_ref-Axios-2024_350-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Axios-2024-350"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>349<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>350<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> with increased penalties if trade partners manipulate their currency or engage in unfair trade practices.<sup id="cite_ref-AP_Trump_Plans_292-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AP_Trump_Plans-292"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump called for 100% tariffs on cars made outside the United States and a minimum 60% tariff on Chinese goods.<sup id="cite_ref-Axios-2024_350-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Axios-2024-350"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>349<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump stated his plans to urge Congress to pass a Trump Reciprocal Trade Act to bestow presidential authority to impose a reciprocal tariff on any country that imposed one on the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-AP_Trump_Plans_292-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AP_Trump_Plans-292"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i>The Washington Post</i> reported in January 2024 that Trump was preparing for a massive trade war.<sup id="cite_ref-trump-china-trade-war_352-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-trump-china-trade-war-352"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>351<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump's trade policies were described as <a href="/wiki/Protectionist" class="mw-redirect" title="Protectionist">protectionist</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>352<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> neo-<a href="/wiki/Mercantilist" class="mw-redirect" title="Mercantilist">mercantilist</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Autarkist" class="mw-redirect" title="Autarkist">autarkist</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2023-6_349-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2023-6-349"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>348<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>353<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and increasing inflation became a more common critique of Trump's economic plans.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>354<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>355<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>356<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>357<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In June 2024, 16 <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Economics" class="mw-redirect" title="Nobel Prize in Economics">Nobel Prize in Economics</a> laureates signed an open letter arguing that Trump's fiscal and trade policies coupled with efforts to limit the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Reserve" title="Federal Reserve">Federal Reserve</a>'s independence would reignite inflation in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>358<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>359<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>360<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Moody%27s_Corporation" title="Moody's Corporation">Moody's</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>361<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> as well as most economists surveyed by <i>The Wall Street Journal</i> in July 2024, predicted that inflation would be worse under Trump than Biden, a result due in part to tariffs, a crack down on illegal immigration, and larger deficits.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>362<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump incorrectly insisted foreign exporters pay tariffs imposed by the U.S. government; American importers pay tariffs on goods upon arrival at U.S. ports, meaning tariffs are taxes that raise prices for imported products Americans buy.<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>363<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>364<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-WD_366-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WD-366"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>365<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> One non-partisan analysis estimated the proposed tariffs would cost $1,700 per year for the average household.<sup id="cite_ref-WD_366-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WD-366"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>365<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Committee_for_a_Responsible_Federal_Budget" title="Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget">Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget</a> found that Trump's plans would grow the national debt at roughly twice the rate of Harris' plan,<sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>366<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> while the <a href="/wiki/Institute_on_Taxation_and_Economic_Policy" title="Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy">Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy</a> found Trump's plan would only benefit the top 5% of earners.<sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>367<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Education">Education</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_the_United_States" title="Education in the United States">Education in the United States</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_2024_presidential_campaign#Education" title="Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign">Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign &nbsp;Education</a>, <a href="/wiki/2020s_controversies_around_critical_race_theory" class="mw-redirect" title="2020s controversies around critical race theory">2020s controversies around critical race theory</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Parental_rights_movement" title="Parental rights movement">Parental rights movement</a></div>
<p>Trump pledged to terminate the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Department_of_Education" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Department of Education">U.S. Department of Education</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-AP_Trump_Plans_292-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AP_Trump_Plans-292"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>368<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>369<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> claiming it has been infiltrated by "radical zealots and Marxists".<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>370<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/American_Federation_of_Teachers" title="American Federation of Teachers">American Federation of Teachers</a> national convention, Harris attacked <a href="/wiki/Book_banning_in_the_United_States_(2021%E2%80%93present)" title="Book banning in the United States (2021present)">recent efforts to ban books in school libraries</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>371<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> She also previously called for raising teachers' wages.<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>372<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Healthcare_issues">Healthcare issues</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Kamala_Harris_2024_presidential_campaign#Healthcare" title="Kamala Harris 2024 presidential campaign">Kamala Harris 2024 presidential campaign &nbsp;Healthcare</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_2024_presidential_campaign#Healthcare_and_social_services" title="Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign">Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign &nbsp;Healthcare and social services</a></div>
<p>Unlike previous elections, healthcare reform played a much more minor role in the 2024 presidential election.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>373<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris stated that she no longer supported a <a href="/wiki/Singlepayer_healthcare_in_the_United_States" class="mw-redirect" title="Singlepayer healthcare in the United States">single-payer healthcare</a> system as she had in 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-CNN-2024_375-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNN-2024-375"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>374<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Instead, she said she intended to protect and expand items legislated during the <a href="/wiki/Obama_administration" class="mw-redirect" title="Obama administration">Obama</a> and <a href="/wiki/Biden_administration" class="mw-redirect" title="Biden administration">Biden administrations</a>. She said she would "maintain and grow" the <a href="/wiki/Affordable_Care_Act" title="Affordable Care Act">Affordable Care Act</a>, while Trump said that he would replace it with his own healthcare plan.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>375<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris also supported limiting yearly out-of-pocket drug costs for seniors, and expanding the $35 cap on insulin for seniors on <a href="/wiki/Medicare_(United_States)" title="Medicare (United States)">Medicare</a> to younger individuals in the program as well.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Hill-2024_285-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Hill-2024-285"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>284<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Generally, both candidates supported using the government to rein in prescription drug costs.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>376<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump suggested he was open to cutting entitlement programs, such as <a href="/wiki/Social_Security_(United_States)" title="Social Security (United States)">Social Security</a> and <a href="/wiki/Medicare_(United_States)" title="Medicare (United States)">Medicare</a>, part of an effort to "[cut] waste" as described by his campaign. During his first term, several budget proposals did suggest cuts to the programs.<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>377<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>378<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Additionally, Vance and Speaker of the House <a href="/wiki/Mike_Johnson" title="Mike Johnson">Mike Johnson</a> suggested cuts to the ACA, including around <a href="/wiki/Pre-existing_condition" title="Pre-existing condition">pre-existing conditions</a>, were part of Trump's plan.<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>379<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> After <a href="/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy_Jr." title="Robert F. Kennedy Jr.">Robert F. Kennedy Jr.</a> dropped out of the race and endorsed Trump, Kennedy advocated for his "<a href="/wiki/Make_America_Healthy_Again" title="Make America Healthy Again">Make America Healthy Again</a>" agenda, pledging to combat the upward trend in chronic disease patients, with Trump saying Kennedy would "go wild" regarding policy on food and medicines.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>380<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>381<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Foreign_policy">Foreign policy</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_2024_presidential_campaign#Foreign_policy" title="Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign">Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign &nbsp;Foreign policy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kamala_Harris_2024_presidential_campaign#Foreign_policy" title="Kamala Harris 2024 presidential campaign">Kamala Harris 2024 presidential campaign &nbsp;Foreign policy</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:P20220221ES-0298-1_(51974425940).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/P20220221ES-0298-1_%2851974425940%29.jpg/250px-P20220221ES-0298-1_%2851974425940%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/P20220221ES-0298-1_%2851974425940%29.jpg/500px-P20220221ES-0298-1_%2851974425940%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2000"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a> signing <a href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Executive_Order_14065" class="extiw" title="s:Executive Order 14065">Executive Order 14065</a> in February 2022 in response to Russia's imminent invasion of Ukraine. The United States has given <a href="/wiki/List_of_military_aid_to_Ukraine_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="List of military aid to Ukraine during the Russo-Ukrainian War">billions worth of military aid</a> to Ukraine following the Russian invasion of the country in 2022.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="Russian invasion of Ukraine">Russian invasion of Ukraine</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Gaza_war" title="Gaza war">Gaza war</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_expansionism" title="Chinese expansionism">Chinese expansionism</a> were some of the main foreign policy issues of the election. Harris signaled she would generally follow Biden's foreign policy on <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> and Ukraine, supporting both in the aftermath of the Russian invasion.<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-3_237-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-3-237"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Reuters-2024-3_383-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters-2024-3-383"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>382<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A supporter of the <a href="/wiki/Two-state_solution" title="Two-state solution">two-state solution</a> to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict,<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-3_237-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-3-237"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>383<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris was expected to continue Biden's approach;<sup id="cite_ref-Al_Jazeera-2024_385-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Al_Jazeera-2024-385"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>384<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> she was seen as tougher on Israel and more sympathetic to Palestinians than Biden or Trump.<sup id="cite_ref-Reuters-2024-3_383-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters-2024-3-383"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>382<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris advocated for "de-risking" from China, a policy that encourages reducing Western economic dependence on China.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>385<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris was expected to continue deepening American alliances in Asia and the Pacific with the intention of curbing China's rising power both economically and militarily.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>386<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Trump's 2024 campaign promoted an <a href="/wiki/Isolationist" class="mw-redirect" title="Isolationist">isolationist</a>, "<a href="/wiki/America_First" title="America First">America First</a>" foreign policy.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT_NATO_Withdrawal_388-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_NATO_Withdrawal-388"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>387<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>388<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump said that America's allies "treat us actually worse than our so-called enemies", and added: "We protect them and then they screw us on trade." He also vowed to impose <a href="/wiki/Tariff" title="Tariff">tariffs</a> on trade partners; economists said this could spark <a href="/wiki/Trade_war" title="Trade war">trade wars</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>389<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> He promised to "fundamentally reevaluate" NATO, shifting the country's defense spending from Europe towards Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-AP_Trump_Plans_292-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AP_Trump_Plans-292"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Although NATO members are <a href="/wiki/Article_5_of_the_North_Atlantic_Treaty" class="mw-redirect" title="Article 5 of the North Atlantic Treaty">obliged to defend</a> any other member who is attacked, Trump said he would encourage Russia to "do whatever the hell they want" to NATO allies that did not spend enough on defense.<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>390<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> NATO Secretary-General <a href="/wiki/Jens_Stoltenberg" title="Jens Stoltenberg">Jens Stoltenberg</a> responded: "Any suggestion that allies will not defend each other undermines all of our security."<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>391<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump vowed that even before he was inaugurated,<sup id="cite_ref-AP_Trump_Plans_292-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AP_Trump_Plans-292"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> he would negotiate an end to the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="Russo-Ukrainian War">Russo-Ukrainian War</a> in one day,<sup id="cite_ref-NYT_NATO_Withdrawal_388-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_NATO_Withdrawal-388"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>387<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> He promised to quickly cut the amount of military and financial aid to Ukraine,<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>392<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and make Europeans reimburse the United States the cost of rebuilding its old stockpiles;<sup id="cite_ref-AP_Trump_Plans_292-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AP_Trump_Plans-292"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> however, most of the money for Ukraine actually goes to American factories that make weapons and military equipment.<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>393<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>394<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>395<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump previously said he might recognize <a href="/wiki/Russia%27s_illegal_annexation_of_Crimea" class="mw-redirect" title="Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea">Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>396<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and suggested the 2022 invasion could have been prevented by Ukraine giving up parts of its own country to Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT_NATO_Withdrawal_388-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_NATO_Withdrawal-388"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>387<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump was seen as more pro-Israel and less sympathetic to Palestine than Biden or Harris.<sup id="cite_ref-TI_398-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TI-398"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>397<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump promised a tougher stance against China,<sup id="cite_ref-trump-china-trade-war_352-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-trump-china-trade-war-352"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>351<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and at the same time questioned whether the United States should defend <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>398<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump suggested withdrawing troops from South Korea if it does not pay more to support American troops there.<sup id="cite_ref-Time-2024_241-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Time-2024-241"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>240<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Gaza_war_views">Gaza war views</h4></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:16.Rally.March4Gaza.FP.WDC.13January2024_(53463909030).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/16.Rally.March4Gaza.FP.WDC.13January2024_%2853463909030%29.jpg/250px-16.Rally.March4Gaza.FP.WDC.13January2024_%2853463909030%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/16.Rally.March4Gaza.FP.WDC.13January2024_%2853463909030%29.jpg/500px-16.Rally.March4Gaza.FP.WDC.13January2024_%2853463909030%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="6000" data-file-height="4000"></a><figcaption>Demonstrators at the <a href="/wiki/March_on_Washington_for_Gaza" title="March on Washington for Gaza">March on Washington for Gaza</a> in January 2024</figcaption></figure>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Gaza_war_protest_vote_movements" title="Gaza war protest vote movements">Gaza war protest vote movements</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gaza_war_protests_in_the_United_States" title="Gaza war protests in the United States">Gaza war protests in the United States</a></div>
<p>Polling indicated that the majority of voters support a ceasefire and American mediation in the <a href="/wiki/Gaza_war" title="Gaza war">Gaza war</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>399<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> According to a <a href="/wiki/YouGov" title="YouGov">YouGov</a> poll in March 2024, 52% of Americans supported stopping weapons shipments to Israel, coming largely from Americans who voted for Biden in 2020 (62% support) and people who did not vote in 2020 (60%). Republicans opposed halting weapons shipments by 25 points.<sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>400<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Republicans generally supported arms to Israel, while Democrats were divided on the issue.<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>401<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Harris was expected to largely continue Biden's approach to the <a href="/wiki/Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_conflict" title="IsraeliPalestinian conflict">IsraeliPalestinian conflict</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Al_Jazeera-2024_385-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Al_Jazeera-2024-385"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>384<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> although she is seen as tougher on Israel and more sympathetic to Palestinians than Biden or Trump.<sup id="cite_ref-Reuters-2024-3_383-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters-2024-3-383"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>382<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/2023_Hamas-led_attack_on_Israel" class="mw-redirect" title="2023 Hamas-led attack on Israel">2023 Hamas-led attack on Israel</a>, Harris at first supported Israel's offensive,<sup id="cite_ref-ABC_News-2024_403-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ABC_News-2024-403"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>402<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Al_Jazeera-2024_385-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Al_Jazeera-2024-385"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>384<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> saying "the threat <a href="/wiki/Hamas" title="Hamas">Hamas</a> poses to the people of Israel must be eliminated".<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-3_237-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-3-237"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Since then, she criticized Israel's actions and the <a href="/wiki/Gaza_humanitarian_crisis_(2023%E2%80%93present)" title="Gaza humanitarian crisis (2023present)">Gaza humanitarian crisis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Reuters-2024-3_383-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters-2024-3-383"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>382<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In March 2024, Harris opposed Israel's <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Rafah" class="mw-redirect" title="Invasion of Rafah">invasion of Rafah</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-3_237-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-3-237"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> called for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza,<sup id="cite_ref-Al_Jazeera-2024_385-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Al_Jazeera-2024-385"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>384<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-3_237-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-3-237"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and called the situation in Gaza a "humanitarian catastrophe".<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-3_237-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-3-237"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris supported continued aid to Israel and Palestine but insisted that Israel should agree to <a href="/wiki/2025_Gaza_war_ceasefire" title="2025 Gaza war ceasefire">a ceasefire and hostage deal</a> and both sides should move towards a <a href="/wiki/Two-state_solution" title="Two-state solution">two-state solution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Israel_404-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Israel-404"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>403<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the Democratic primaries, the <a href="/wiki/Uncommitted_National_Movement" title="Uncommitted National Movement">Uncommitted National Movement</a> led a protest campaign against Biden over the war, calling for a ceasefire and <a href="/wiki/Arms_embargo_on_Israel" class="mw-redirect" title="Arms embargo on Israel">arms embargo on Israel</a>. It received over 700,000 votes and 36 delegates.<sup id="cite_ref-dnc-uncommitted-arab_405-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dnc-uncommitted-arab-405"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>404<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris was seen as more sympathetic to Palestinians, and she and her campaign interacted more with Arab-American and Uncommitted leaders;<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>405<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-dnc-uncommitted-arab_405-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dnc-uncommitted-arab-405"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>404<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> however, Harris refused to halt weapons shipments to Israel or shift policy much from Biden, saying Israel has a right to defend itself.<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>406<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>407<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> By October, Uncommitted encouraged its members to vote for Harris.<sup id="cite_ref-Weisman_1082024_409-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Weisman_1082024-409"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>408<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>During his first term as president, Trump consistently supported Israel.<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>409<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> He presented himself as a stronger defender of Israel than Biden, and was seen as less sympathetic to Palestine than Biden or Harris.<sup id="cite_ref-TI_398-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TI-398"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>397<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump was expected to continue arming Israel, likely with "no strings attached" for humanitarian concerns.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>410<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> He voiced strong support for Israel's war on Hamas and Gaza, saying that Israel must "finish the problem".<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>411<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump told donors he would "crush" pro-Palestinian protests, deport non-citizen protesters, and "set the movement back 25 or 30 years".<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>412<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>413<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump said he would ban Gaza residents from entering the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>414<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> At times, he was critical of Israel's war in Gaza, saying Israel should "get it over with ... get back to peace and stop killing people".<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>415<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>416<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Israeli-American billionaire <a href="/wiki/Miriam_Adelson" title="Miriam Adelson">Miriam Adelson</a> sought support from candidate Trump for Israel's <a href="/wiki/Proposed_Israeli_annexation_of_the_West_Bank" title="Proposed Israeli annexation of the West Bank">annexation</a> of the <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a>, pledging more than $100 million to Trump's campaign in exchange for U.S. recognition of Israel's sovereignty over the region.<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>417<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>418<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In January 2025, the <i><a href="/wiki/Times_of_Israel" class="mw-redirect" title="Times of Israel">Times of Israel</a></i> reported that Adelson gave Trump's campaign at least $100 million in October 2024, making her that campaign's third largest donor.<sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>419<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="LGBTQ_rights">LGBTQ rights</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/LGBTQ_rights_in_the_United_States" title="LGBTQ rights in the United States">LGBTQ rights in the United States</a> and <a href="/wiki/Transgender_rights_in_the_United_States" title="Transgender rights in the United States">Transgender rights in the United States</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Kamala_Harris_2024_presidential_campaign#LGBTQ_rights" title="Kamala Harris 2024 presidential campaign">Kamala Harris 2024 presidential campaign &nbsp;LGBTQ rights</a>, <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_2024_presidential_campaign#LGBTQ_rights_and_civil_rights" title="Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign">Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign &nbsp;LGBTQ rights and civil rights</a>, and <a href="/wiki/2020s_anti-LGBTQ_movement_in_the_United_States" title="2020s anti-LGBTQ movement in the United States">2020s anti-LGBTQ movement in the United States</a></div>
<p>In the 2020s, conservative politicians in state legislatures introduced a growing number of bills that restrict the rights of LGBTQ people, especially transgender people.<sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>420<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A strong supporter of LGBTQ people's rights,<sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>421<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris denounced legislative attacks on transgender rights in states across the country.<sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>422<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>423<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump promised to roll back policies regarding transgender individuals.<sup id="cite_ref-Axios-2023_425-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Axios-2023-425"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>424<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris and Walz campaigned as supporters of LGBTQ+ rights.<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>425<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>426<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump stated he would rescind Biden's <a href="/wiki/Title_IX" title="Title IX">Title IX</a> protections "on day one" for transgender students using bathrooms, locker rooms, and pronouns that align with their gender identities.<sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>427<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump stated he would enact a federal law that would recognize only two genders and claimed that being transgender is a concept only recently manufactured by "the radical left".<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>428<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump previously withdrew Title IX provisions that allowed transgender youth to have access to the bathrooms of their choice, and he attempted to roll-back several transgender-related policies in the <a href="/wiki/Affordable_Care_Act" title="Affordable Care Act">Affordable Care Act</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Axios-2023_425-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Axios-2023-425"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>424<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump repeated a false claim that children undergo transgender surgery while at school, without parental knowledge or consent.<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>429<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>430<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> His campaign's "<a href="/wiki/Kamala_is_for_they/them,_President_Trump_is_for_you" class="mw-redirect" title="Kamala is for they/them, President Trump is for you">Kamala is for they/them, President Trump is for you</a>" <a href="/wiki/Attack_ad" title="Attack ad">attack ad</a> was the most effective of the campaign, shifting the race 2.7 percentage points in favor of Trump after viewers watched it.<sup id="cite_ref-nyt20241107_432-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt20241107-432"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>431<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Election-related_violence">Election-related violence</h2></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Assassination_attempts_on_Trump">Assassination attempts on Trump</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Donald_Trump_in_Pennsylvania" title="Attempted assassination of Donald Trump in Pennsylvania">Attempted assassination of Donald Trump in Pennsylvania</a> and <a href="/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Donald_Trump_in_Florida" title="Attempted assassination of Donald Trump in Florida">Attempted assassination of Donald Trump in Florida</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Former_President_Donald_Trump_paying_respect_to_Corey_Comperatore_(53887491621).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Former_President_Donald_Trump_paying_respect_to_Corey_Comperatore_%2853887491621%29.jpg/250px-Former_President_Donald_Trump_paying_respect_to_Corey_Comperatore_%2853887491621%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Former_President_Donald_Trump_paying_respect_to_Corey_Comperatore_%2853887491621%29.jpg/500px-Former_President_Donald_Trump_paying_respect_to_Corey_Comperatore_%2853887491621%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="800"></a><figcaption>Trump at the <a href="/wiki/2024_Republican_National_Convention" title="2024 Republican National Convention">RNC</a> standing alongside the fire department uniform of Corey Comperatore, who was killed during the attempted assassination of Trump</figcaption></figure>
<p>On July 13, 2024, Trump survived <a href="/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Donald_Trump_in_Pennsylvania" title="Attempted assassination of Donald Trump in Pennsylvania">an assassination attempt</a> while addressing a <a href="/wiki/Campaign_rally" class="mw-redirect" title="Campaign rally">campaign rally</a> near <a href="/wiki/Butler,_Pennsylvania" title="Butler, Pennsylvania">Butler, Pennsylvania</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Pennsylvania_Assassination_433-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pennsylvania_Assassination-433"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>432<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump was shot and wounded on his right ear by <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Matthew_Crooks" title="Thomas Matthew Crooks">Thomas Matthew Crooks</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-9_434-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-9-434"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>433<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>434<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> who fired eight rounds with an <a href="/wiki/AR-15%E2%80%93style_rifle" title="AR-15style rifle">AR-15style rifle</a> from the roof of a building approximately 400 feet (120 metres) from the stage; the shots killed one audience member and critically injured two others.<sup id="cite_ref-The_New_York_Times-2024-9_434-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2024-9-434"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>433<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Seconds later, Crooks was shot and killed by the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Secret_Service%27s_counter-sniper_team" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Secret Service's counter-sniper team">U.S. Secret Service's counter-sniper team</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>435<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On September 11, 2024, a bipartisan Senate report identified tech issues and other preventable mistakes by the Secret Service during the event.<sup id="cite_ref-nbc25_437-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nbc25-437"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>436<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> 
</p><p>On September 15, 2024, Trump survived <a href="/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Donald_Trump_in_Florida" title="Attempted assassination of Donald Trump in Florida">a separate assassination attempt</a> at <a href="/wiki/Trump_International_Golf_Club_(West_Palm_Beach)" title="Trump International Golf Club (West Palm Beach)">Trump International Golf Club</a> in <a href="/wiki/West_Palm_Beach,_Florida" title="West Palm Beach, Florida">West Palm Beach, Florida</a>. The suspect did not fire his weapon, and no deaths or injuries were reported.<sup id="cite_ref-Florida_Assassination_438-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Florida_Assassination-438"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>437<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The suspect, <a href="/wiki/Ryan_Wesley_Routh" title="Ryan Wesley Routh">Ryan Wesley Routh</a>, is in custody.<sup id="cite_ref-CNN_Sept_439-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNN_Sept-439"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>438<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Violence_towards_election_workers">Violence towards election workers</h3></div>
<p>Since the 2020 election and continuing into the 2024 election, the <a href="/wiki/Election_denial_movement_in_the_United_States" title="Election denial movement in the United States">election denial movement</a> prompted thousands of <a href="/wiki/Death_threat" title="Death threat">death threats</a> directed at election workers, officials, and their families, with some receiving letters laced with <a href="/wiki/Fentanyl" title="Fentanyl">fentanyl</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>439<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-441" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-441"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>440<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As of March 2024, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice" title="United States Department of Justice">Department of Justice's</a> Election Threats Task Force had charged 20 people with threat-related crimes.<sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>441<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In September 2024, suspicious packages were sent to state election officials in several states, which resulted in evacuations. The inclusion of white powder in most of the packages mirrored the <a href="/wiki/2001_anthrax_attacks" title="2001 anthrax attacks">2001 anthrax attacks</a>; the substance in Oklahoma packages was identified as flour.<sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>442<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Threats led some election workers to resign, and affected recruitment of temporary <a href="/wiki/Poll_workers" class="mw-redirect" title="Poll workers">poll workers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-VD_444-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VD-444"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>443<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-HT_445-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HT-445"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>444<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In locations where funds were available,<sup id="cite_ref-HT_445-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HT-445"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>444<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> efforts to protect election workers involved <a href="/wiki/Active_shooter_training" title="Active shooter training">active shooter training</a>, provision of <a href="/wiki/First_aid_kit" title="First aid kit">first aid kits</a> and <a href="/wiki/Narcan" class="mw-redirect" title="Narcan">Narcan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bulletproof_vest" title="Bulletproof vest">bulletproof vests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bulletproof_glass" title="Bulletproof glass">bulletproof glass</a>, <a href="/wiki/Metal_detector" title="Metal detector">metal detectors</a>, armed guards, <a href="/wiki/Police_sniper" class="mw-redirect" title="Police sniper">police snipers</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle" title="Unmanned aerial vehicle">drones</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-VD_444-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VD-444"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>443<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Violence_towards_voters">Violence towards voters</h3></div>
<p>On October 30, 2024, an 18-year-old man in <a href="/wiki/Jacksonville,_Florida" title="Jacksonville, Florida">Jacksonville, Florida</a>, was arrested for <a href="/wiki/Aggravated_assault" class="mw-redirect" title="Aggravated assault">aggravated assault</a> and <a href="/wiki/Improper_exhibition_of_a_dangerous_weapon" class="mw-redirect" title="Improper exhibition of a dangerous weapon">improper exhibition of a dangerous weapon</a> after brandishing a machete at two women outside an early voting center. He, along with seven other teenagers, allegedly approached and antagonized members of the opposing political party as they were demonstrating. Neither the teenager's nor the women's political parties were disclosed, although later posts by the Duval Democratic Party described the teenager's party as a "group of young men carrying Trump flags".<sup id="cite_ref-446" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-446"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>445<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On November 1, 2024, a voter wearing a "<a href="/wiki/Let%27s_Go_Brandon" title="Let's Go Brandon">Let's Go Brandon</a>" hat was reportedly struck by a poll worker after a verbal altercation over his hat at an <a href="/wiki/Orangeburg_County,_South_Carolina" title="Orangeburg County, South Carolina">Orangeburg County, South Carolina</a>, polling location.<sup id="cite_ref-447" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-447"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>446<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Also on November 1, a man in <a href="/wiki/Bath,_New_York" title="Bath, New York">Bath, New York</a>, was arrested for assaulting someone in a supermarket for wearing a Trump hat.<sup id="cite_ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>447<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Arson_of_ballot_boxes">Arson of ballot boxes</h3></div>
<p>In late October 2024, multiple fires were reported at ballot drop boxes in <a href="/wiki/Portland,_Oregon" title="Portland, Oregon">Portland, Oregon</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vancouver,_Washington" title="Vancouver, Washington">Vancouver, Washington</a>. The fires damaged hundreds of ballots, requiring election officials to identify and offer new ballots to those affected by the fires. Prior to the fires, the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation" title="Federal Bureau of Investigation">Federal Bureau of Investigation</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Homeland_Security" class="mw-redirect" title="Department of Homeland Security">Department of Homeland Security</a> had issued a bulletin raising concerns that "election-related grievances" could motivate domestic extremist activity and that ballot drop boxes could potentially be "attractive targets".<sup id="cite_ref-449" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-449"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>448<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-450" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>449<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Phoenix,_Arizona" title="Phoenix, Arizona">Phoenix, Arizona</a>, a fire was started in a mail collection box, destroying some ballots and other mail. A suspect was arrested and claimed that the fire was unrelated to the election.<sup id="cite_ref-451" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-451"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>450<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Timeline">Timeline</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_2024_United_States_presidential_election" title="Timeline of the 2024 United States presidential election">Timeline of the 2024 United States presidential election</a></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Opinion_polling_and_forecasts">Opinion polling and forecasts <span class="anchor" id="Opinion_polling_and_forecasts"></span></h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Nationwide_opinion_polling_for_the_2024_United_States_presidential_election" title="Nationwide opinion polling for the 2024 United States presidential election">Nationwide opinion polling for the 2024 United States presidential election</a></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Electoral_College_forecasts">Electoral College forecasts</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Statewide_opinion_polling_for_the_2024_United_States_presidential_election" title="Statewide opinion polling for the 2024 United States presidential election">Statewide opinion polling for the 2024 United States presidential election</a></div>
<p>Elections analysts and political pundits issue probabilistic forecasts of the composition of the Electoral College. These forecasts use a variety of factors to estimate the likelihood of each candidate winning the Electoral College electors for that state. Most election predictors use the following ratings:
</p>
<ul><li>"<u>tossup</u>": no advantage</li>
<li>"<u>tilt</u>" (used by some predictors): advantage that is not quite as strong as "lean"</li>
<li>"<u>lean</u>" or "<u>leans</u>": slight advantage</li>
<li>"<u>likely</u>": significant, but surmountable, advantage</li>
<li>"<u>very likely</u>" (used by some predictors): massive advantage that is stronger than "likely"</li>
<li>"<u>safe</u>" or "<u>solid</u>": near-certain chance of victory</li></ul>
<p>Below is a list of states considered by one or more forecast to be competitive; states that are deemed to be "safe" or "solid" by forecasters <i><a href="/wiki/The_Cook_Political_Report" class="mw-redirect" title="The Cook Political Report">The Cook Political Report</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Sabato%27s_Crystal_Ball" class="mw-redirect" title="Sabato's Crystal Ball">Sabato's Crystal Ball</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Inside_Elections" class="mw-redirect" title="Inside Elections">Inside Elections</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/CNalysis" class="mw-redirect" title="CNalysis">CNalysis</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Decision_Desk_HQ" title="Decision Desk HQ">Decision Desk HQ</a></i>, and <a href="/wiki/YouGov" title="YouGov">YouGov</a> are omitted for brevity.<sup id="cite_ref-454" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-454"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>b<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Polling_accuracy">Polling accuracy</h4></div>
<p>Following polling inaccuracies in connection with the 2020 presidential election, pollsters took steps to avoid similar errors in 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-468" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-468"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>464<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-469" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-469"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>465<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Despite these efforts, national polls underestimated Trump's support once again in 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-470" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-470"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>466<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2016, national polls were fairly accurate; however, Trump overperformed the polls in Michigan, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin, leading to his Electoral College victory. In 2020, polls had overestimated Biden's margin over Trump by approximately 4% in competitive states.<sup id="cite_ref-471" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-471"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>467<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2024, pollsters underestimated Trump's support by smaller margins than they did in 2016 and 2020,<sup id="cite_ref-472" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-472"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>468<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and their underestimation of that support was within the realm of a <a href="/wiki/Normal_polling_error" class="mw-redirect" title="Normal polling error">normal polling error</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Morris_2024_473-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morris_2024-473"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>469<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Warren_2024_474-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Warren_2024-474"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>470<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Going into the election, most polls showed the race to be neck and neck and within the margin of error.<sup id="cite_ref-475" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-475"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>471<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In every swing state, Trump outperformed his final polling numbers by approximately 3%, which is in line with a typical margin of error.<sup id="cite_ref-476" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-476"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>472<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Compared with the 2020 polls, the margin of error in 2024 in swing states was lower and high-quality national polls were more accurate.<sup id="cite_ref-Warren_2024_474-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Warren_2024-474"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>470<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Polling averages vastly underestimated Trump's strength in both safe red and safe blue states.<sup id="cite_ref-Morris_2024_473-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morris_2024-473"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>469<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-477" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-477"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>473<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Florida and Texas were both projected to go for Trump by about 7%; he won each of them by about 13%.<sup id="cite_ref-Morris_2024_473-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morris_2024-473"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>469<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Pollster <a href="/wiki/Ann_Selzer" title="Ann Selzer">Ann Selzer</a> released a poll in Iowa that had Harris winning the state by 3%,<sup id="cite_ref-478" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-478"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>474<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> only for Trump to take the state by 13%.<sup id="cite_ref-Morris_2024_473-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morris_2024-473"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>469<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On the other hand, New Jersey was projected to be a safe state for Harris but most news stations waited until 90% of the vote was in before calling it for Harris, as she was only leading by 5%.<sup id="cite_ref-479" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-479"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>475<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-480" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-480"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>476<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Debates">Debates</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_debates" title="2024 United States presidential debates">2024 United States presidential debates</a></div>
<p>Biden and Trump agreed to hold debates on <a href="/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a> on June 27 and <a href="/wiki/ABC_News_(United_States)" title="ABC News (United States)">ABC News</a> on September 10.<sup id="cite_ref-481" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-481"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>477<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Biden and Trump debated on June 27, 2024, in <a href="/wiki/Atlanta" title="Atlanta">Atlanta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(U.S._state)" title="Georgia (U.S. state)">Georgia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-482" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-482"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>478<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> After Biden suspended his re-election campaign,<sup id="cite_ref-483" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-483"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>479<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris became the Democratic nominee and debated Trump on September 10, 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-484" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-484"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>480<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Results">Results</h2></div>
<p>Trump won the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Electoral_College" title="United States Electoral College">Electoral College</a> with 312 electoral votes to Harris' 226.<sup id="cite_ref-485" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-485"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>481<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> He prevailed in all seven <a href="/wiki/Swing_state" title="Swing state">swing states</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_486-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-486"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>482<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In addition, Trump won the national <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_presidential_elections_by_popular_vote_margin" title="List of United States presidential elections by popular vote margin">popular vote</a> with a <a href="/wiki/Plurality_(voting)" title="Plurality (voting)">plurality</a> of 49.8%;<sup id="cite_ref-487" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-487"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>483<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris received 48.3%.<sup id="cite_ref-488" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-488"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>484<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On November 6, the day after Election Day, Harris publicly conceded the election to Trump.<sup id="cite_ref-reutersnov7_489-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reutersnov7-489"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>485<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
