<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="States_that_flipped_from_Democratic_to_Republican">States that flipped from Democratic to Republican</h4></div>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Arizona" title="Arizona">Arizona</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Georgia_(U.S._state)" title="Georgia (U.S. state)">Georgia</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Michigan" title="Michigan">Michigan</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Nevada" title="Nevada">Nevada</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania" title="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Wisconsin" title="Wisconsin">Wisconsin</a></li></ul>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Close_states">Close states</h3></div>
<p>The seven <a href="/wiki/Swing_state" title="Swing state">swing states</a> in the 2024 election were the <a href="/wiki/Rust_Belt" title="Rust Belt">Rust Belt</a> states of <a href="/wiki/Wisconsin" title="Wisconsin">Wisconsin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michigan" title="Michigan">Michigan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania" title="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Sun_Belt" title="Sun Belt">Sun Belt</a> states of <a href="/wiki/Arizona" title="Arizona">Arizona</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(U.S._state)" title="Georgia (U.S. state)">Georgia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nevada" title="Nevada">Nevada</a>, and <a href="/wiki/North_Carolina" title="North Carolina">North Carolina</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC-2024_540-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-2024-540"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>535<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>States where the margin of victory was under 1 percentage point (10 electoral votes; all won by Trump):
</p>
<ol><li><span style="color:darkred;background:white"><b>Wisconsin, 0.87% (29,397 votes)  10 electoral votes</b></span></li></ol>
<p>States/districts where the margin of victory was between 1 and 5 percentage points (87 electoral votes; 72 won by Trump, 15 won by Harris):
</p>
<ol><li><span style="color:darkred;background:white"><b>Michigan, 1.41% (80,103 votes)  15 electoral votes</b></span></li>
<li><span style="color:darkred;background:white"><b>Pennsylvania, 1.71% (120,266 votes)  19 electoral votes</b></span> (<a href="/wiki/Tipping-point_state" title="Tipping-point state">tipping-point state</a>)</li>
<li><span style="color:darkred;background:white"><b>Georgia, 2.20% (115,100 votes)  16 electoral votes</b></span></li>
<li><span style="color:darkblue;background:white"><b>New Hampshire, 2.78% (22,965 votes)  4 electoral votes</b></span></li>
<li><span style="color:darkred;background:white"><b>Nevada, 3.10% (46,008 votes)  6 electoral votes</b></span></li>
<li><span style="color:darkred;background:white"><b>North Carolina, 3.21% (183,046 votes)  16 electoral votes</b></span></li>
<li><span style="color:darkblue;background:white"><b>Minnesota, 4.24% (137,947 votes)  10 electoral votes</b></span></li>
<li><span style="color:darkblue;background:white"><b>Nebraska's 2nd congressional district, 4.59% (14,636 votes)  1 electoral vote</b></span></li></ol>
<p>States/districts where the margin of victory was between 5% and 10% (46 electoral votes; 12 won by Trump, 34 by Harris):
</p>
<ol><li><span style="color:darkred;background:white"><b>Arizona, 5.53% (187,382 votes)  11 electoral votes</b></span></li>
<li><span style="color:darkblue;background:white"><b>Virginia, 5.78% (260,310 votes)  13 electoral votes</b></span></li>
<li><span style="color:darkblue;background:white"><b>New Jersey, 5.91% (252,498 votes)   14 electoral votes</b></span></li>
<li><span style="color:darkblue;background:white"><b>New Mexico, 6.00% (55,411 votes)  5 electoral votes</b></span></li>
<li><span style="color:darkblue;background:white"><b>Maine, 6.94% (57,514 votes)  2 electoral votes</b></span></li>
<li><span style="color:darkred;background:white"><b>Maine's 2nd congressional district, 9.03% (33,297 votes)  1 electoral vote</b></span></li></ol>
<p><span style="color:darkred;background:white"><b>Red</b></span> denotes states or congressional districts won by Republican Donald Trump; <span style="color:darkblue;background:white"><b>Blue</b></span> denotes those won by Democrat Kamala Harris.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="County_statistics">County statistics</h3></div>
<p>Counties with highest percentage of Democratic vote:<sup id="cite_ref-541" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-541"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>536<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<ol><li><span style="color:blue"><b><a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">District of Columbia</a>  90.28%</b></span><sup id="cite_ref-542" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-542"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>f<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><span style="color:blue"><b><a href="/wiki/Prince_George%27s_County,_Maryland" title="Prince George's County, Maryland">Prince George's County, Maryland</a>  85.90%</b></span></li>
<li><span style="color:blue"><b><a href="/wiki/Petersburg,_Virginia" title="Petersburg, Virginia">Petersburg, Virginia</a>  85.52%</b></span><sup id="cite_ref-543" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-543"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>g<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><span style="color:blue"><b><a href="/wiki/Baltimore" title="Baltimore">Baltimore, Maryland</a>  84.55%</b></span><sup id="cite_ref-544" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-544"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>h<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><span style="color:blue"><b><a href="/wiki/Oglala_Lakota_County,_South_Dakota" title="Oglala Lakota County, South Dakota">Oglala Lakota County, South Dakota</a>  83.83%</b></span></li></ol>
<p>Counties with highest percentage of Republican vote:
</p>
<ol><li><span style="color:red"><b><a href="/wiki/Grant_County,_Nebraska" title="Grant County, Nebraska">Grant County, Nebraska</a>  95.90%</b></span></li>
<li><span style="color:red"><b><a href="/wiki/Roberts_County,_Texas" title="Roberts County, Texas">Roberts County, Texas</a>  95.63%</b></span></li>
<li><span style="color:red"><b><a href="/wiki/Borden_County,_Texas" title="Borden County, Texas">Borden County, Texas</a>  95.61%</b></span></li>
<li><span style="color:red"><b><a href="/wiki/King_County,_Texas" title="King County, Texas">King County, Texas</a>  95.56%</b></span></li>
<li><span style="color:red"><b><a href="/wiki/Hayes_County,_Nebraska" title="Hayes County, Nebraska">Hayes County, Nebraska</a>  95.55%</b></span></li></ol>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Analysis_of_results">Analysis of results</h2></div>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:1828-_Margin_of_victory_in_US_presidential_elections_-_popular_vote.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/1828-_Margin_of_victory_in_US_presidential_elections_-_popular_vote.svg/330px-1828-_Margin_of_victory_in_US_presidential_elections_-_popular_vote.svg.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="210" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/1828-_Margin_of_victory_in_US_presidential_elections_-_popular_vote.svg/500px-1828-_Margin_of_victory_in_US_presidential_elections_-_popular_vote.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/1828-_Margin_of_victory_in_US_presidential_elections_-_popular_vote.svg/960px-1828-_Margin_of_victory_in_US_presidential_elections_-_popular_vote.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="700"></a><figcaption> Trump's 1.5% <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_presidential_elections_by_popular_vote_margin" title="List of United States presidential elections by popular vote margin">margin of victory</a> in 2024 (shown in chart) places his victory in the 20th percentile of presidential election victory margins since 1828.<sup id="cite_ref-UCSB_20241106_549-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UCSB_20241106-549"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>538<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Presidential_Election_Results_Swing_by_State_from_2020_to_2024.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Presidential_Election_Results_Swing_by_State_from_2020_to_2024.svg/330px-Presidential_Election_Results_Swing_by_State_from_2020_to_2024.svg.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="745" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Presidential_Election_Results_Swing_by_State_from_2020_to_2024.svg/500px-Presidential_Election_Results_Swing_by_State_from_2020_to_2024.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Presidential_Election_Results_Swing_by_State_from_2020_to_2024.svg/600px-Presidential_Election_Results_Swing_by_State_from_2020_to_2024.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="959" data-file-height="2382"></a><figcaption>Vote margin swing by state <a href="/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election" title="2020 United States presidential election">2020</a> to 2024. No state shifted Democratic. Relative to 2016, 28 states shifted to the right by 2024, with an average shift relative to 2016 of 1 point.<sup id="cite_ref-WashPost_20241118_550-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WashPost_20241118-550"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>539<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>Trump is the first president since <a href="/wiki/Grover_Cleveland" title="Grover Cleveland">Grover Cleveland</a> in <a href="/wiki/1892_United_States_presidential_election" title="1892 United States presidential election">1892</a> to win non-consecutive terms.<sup id="cite_ref-hajela_20241106_551-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hajela_20241106-551"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>540<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> 2024 also marked the first time since 1892 that the incumbent party had lost in each of three consecutive presidential elections.<sup id="cite_ref-552" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-552"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>541<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump is the first Republican since <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a> in 2004 to win the popular vote and the first Republican since George W. Bush to win a second term in the White House. Trump is also the first non-incumbent Republican to have won the popular vote since <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">George H. W. Bush</a> in 1988.<sup id="cite_ref-hillnov6_553-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hillnov6-553"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>542<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-554" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-554"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>543<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump won a 1.48% margin of victory.<sup id="cite_ref-Cook_555-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cook-555"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>544<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> While winning the popular vote, Trump did not win a majority of the popular vote; he is the first Republican since <a href="/wiki/Richard_Nixon" title="Richard Nixon">Richard Nixon</a> in 1968 to win the popular vote with a plurality.<sup id="cite_ref-Kilgore_11222024_556-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kilgore_11222024-556"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>545<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump is also the first presidential candidate since Nixon in 1968 to successfully make a political comeback by winning an election after losing a previous one.
</p><p>Trump carried 31 of 50 states.<sup id="cite_ref-557" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-557"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>546<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump is the first Republican presidential candidate to win Nevada since George W. Bush in 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-558" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-558"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>547<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The 2024 presidential election was the first presidential election since <a href="/wiki/1976_United_States_presidential_election" title="1976 United States presidential election">1976</a> in which all 50 states and Washington, D.C. shifted towards the same party.<sup id="cite_ref-swing_wide_559-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-swing_wide-559"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>548<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-560" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-560"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>549<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Approximately 90% of counties swung towards Trump between the 2020 and 2024 elections, encompassing both rural and urban areas.<sup id="cite_ref-Red_Shift_561-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Red_Shift-561"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>550<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The 2024 election was the first presidential election since <a href="/wiki/1932_United_States_presidential_election" title="1932 United States presidential election">1932</a> in which the losing candidate failed to flip a single county.<sup id="cite_ref-562" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-562"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>551<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Even among states that voted heavily for Biden in the 2020 election, Trump's gains were significant.<sup id="cite_ref-563" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-563"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>552<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The states of <a href="/wiki/New_York_(state)" title="New York (state)">New York</a> and <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a> swung over ten points toward Trump, and Trump also made gains in Harris's home state of <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nyt-results-president_547-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-results-president-547"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>537<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> 
</p><p>While Trump made gains among young voters compared to Republicans in recent presidential elections, especially among young men,<sup id="cite_ref-Lange_1162024_564-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lange_1162024-564"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>553<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> exit polls found Harris won young voters by 51 to 54 percent of voters under 30.<sup id="cite_ref-565" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-565"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>554<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Almost all demographic groups (including African-Americans, Hispanic-Americans, and Asian-Americans)<sup id="cite_ref-566" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-566"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>555<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> swung towards Trump from the 2020 election; the exceptions to this trend included non-religious voters, LGBT voters, White women with college degrees, Black women, and voters making over $100,000 a year. According to exit polls, Harris's strongest income demographic consisted of voters making over $200,000 a year; she won those voters by a margin of 5246%.<sup id="cite_ref-Poorer_voters_567-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Poorer_voters-567"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>556<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Post-election research by the <a href="/wiki/Brookings_Institution" title="Brookings Institution">Brookings Institution</a> found that while Trump made inroads with minority voters, the Republican Party had "hardly" created a multiracial coalition. Brookings argued that saying so was premature and that such support "could very well be a blip" based on economic concerns.<sup id="cite_ref-568" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-568"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>557<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Aged 78 on Election Day, Trump is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States_by_age" title="List of presidents of the United States by age">oldest person</a> ever to be elected U.S. president;<sup id="cite_ref-hajela_20241106_551-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hajela_20241106-551"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>540<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump is also the first former president to win a state since <a href="/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt" title="Theodore Roosevelt">Theodore Roosevelt</a> in <a href="/wiki/1912_United_States_presidential_election" title="1912 United States presidential election">1912</a>. This was the first election since <a href="/wiki/1944_United_States_presidential_election" title="1944 United States presidential election">1944</a> in which a presidential candidate won two elections with different vice presidential candidates; Trump replaced his 2016 and 2020 running mate, <a href="/wiki/Mike_Pence" title="Mike Pence">Mike Pence</a>, with Vance.<sup id="cite_ref-569" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-569"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>558<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Aftermath">Aftermath</h2></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><span><audio id="mwe_player_2" controls="" preload="none" data-mw-tmh="" class="mw-file-element" width="250" style="width:250px;" data-durationhint="173" data-mwtitle="Donald_Trump_projected_winner_in_US_presidential_race.opus" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" resource="/wiki/File:Donald_Trump_projected_winner_in_US_presidential_race.opus"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/8/82/Donald_Trump_projected_winner_in_US_presidential_race.opus/Donald_Trump_projected_winner_in_US_presidential_race.opus.ogg" type="audio/ogg; codecs=&quot;vorbis&quot;" data-transcodekey="ogg" data-width="0" data-height="0"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/82/Donald_Trump_projected_winner_in_US_presidential_race.opus" type="audio/ogg; codecs=&quot;opus&quot;" data-width="0" data-height="0"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/8/82/Donald_Trump_projected_winner_in_US_presidential_race.opus/Donald_Trump_projected_winner_in_US_presidential_race.opus.mp3" type="audio/mpeg" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" data-height="0"></audio></span><figcaption>A <a href="/wiki/Voice_of_America" title="Voice of America">Voice of America</a> report on Trump's victory</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Peter_Boghossian_(12).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Peter_Boghossian_%2812%29.jpg/250px-Peter_Boghossian_%2812%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="188" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Peter_Boghossian_%2812%29.jpg/500px-Peter_Boghossian_%2812%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="3000"></a><figcaption>MCC-CFR Election Night with <a href="/wiki/Peter_Boghossian" title="Peter Boghossian">Peter Boghossian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gladden_Pappin" title="Gladden Pappin">Gladden Pappin</a>, and Mikls Sznth</figcaption></figure>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Reactions">Reactions</h3></div>
<p>Crisis services for the LGBTQ+ community saw a sharp increase in usage during the election week. <a href="/wiki/The_Trevor_Project" title="The Trevor Project">The Trevor Project</a>'s crisis lines saw a 125% increase since around midnight on election night according to a statement by CEO Jaymes Black on November 6, and followed an about 200% increase in election related conversations that had been seen between November 34. By November 8, it was reported that the organization saw an overall increase by 700%. The <a href="/wiki/Crisis_Text_Line" title="Crisis Text Line">Crisis Text Line</a> also reported that 56% of their users reported as LGBTQ+ on election day.<sup id="cite_ref-570" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-570"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>559<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-571" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-571"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>560<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>A company that assists wealthy Americans in securing foreign citizenship saw a 200 jump in inquiries following the election.<sup id="cite_ref-572" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-572"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>561<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Political">Political</h4></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><span><video id="mwe_player_3" poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Harris_concedes_presidential_win_to_Trump_-_VOA_News.webm/250px--Harris_concedes_presidential_win_to_Trump_-_VOA_News.webm.jpg" controls="" preload="none" data-mw-tmh="" class="mw-file-element" width="250" height="141" data-durationhint="231" data-mwtitle="Harris_concedes_presidential_win_to_Trump_-_VOA_News.webm" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" resource="/wiki/File:Harris_concedes_presidential_win_to_Trump_-_VOA_News.webm"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/7c/Harris_concedes_presidential_win_to_Trump_-_VOA_News.webm/Harris_concedes_presidential_win_to_Trump_-_VOA_News.webm.480p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-transcodekey="480p.vp9.webm" data-width="854" data-height="480"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/7c/Harris_concedes_presidential_win_to_Trump_-_VOA_News.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-width="1920" data-height="1080"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/7c/Harris_concedes_presidential_win_to_Trump_-_VOA_News.webm/Harris_concedes_presidential_win_to_Trump_-_VOA_News.webm.720p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-transcodekey="720p.vp9.webm" data-width="1280" data-height="720"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/7c/Harris_concedes_presidential_win_to_Trump_-_VOA_News.webm/Harris_concedes_presidential_win_to_Trump_-_VOA_News.webm.1080p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-transcodekey="1080p.vp9.webm" data-width="1920" data-height="1080"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/7c/Harris_concedes_presidential_win_to_Trump_-_VOA_News.webm/Harris_concedes_presidential_win_to_Trump_-_VOA_News.webm.144p.mjpeg.mov" type="video/quicktime" data-transcodekey="144p.mjpeg.mov" data-width="256" data-height="144"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/7c/Harris_concedes_presidential_win_to_Trump_-_VOA_News.webm/Harris_concedes_presidential_win_to_Trump_-_VOA_News.webm.240p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-transcodekey="240p.vp9.webm" data-width="426" data-height="240"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/7c/Harris_concedes_presidential_win_to_Trump_-_VOA_News.webm/Harris_concedes_presidential_win_to_Trump_-_VOA_News.webm.360p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-transcodekey="360p.vp9.webm" data-width="640" data-height="360"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/7c/Harris_concedes_presidential_win_to_Trump_-_VOA_News.webm/Harris_concedes_presidential_win_to_Trump_-_VOA_News.webm.360p.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp8, vorbis&quot;" data-transcodekey="360p.webm" data-width="640" data-height="360"></video></span><figcaption>Harris conceded victory to Trump on November 6.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Democrats had differing views on why Harris lost the election. Vermont Senator <a href="/wiki/Bernie_Sanders" title="Bernie Sanders">Bernie Sanders</a> blamed Democrats for having abandoned the working class.<sup id="cite_ref-573" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-573"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>562<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Democratic_National_Committee" title="Democratic National Committee">Democratic National Committee</a> chair <a href="/wiki/Jaime_Harrison" title="Jaime Harrison">Jaime Harrison</a> dismissed Sanders' criticism.<sup id="cite_ref-574" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-574"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>563<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-575" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-575"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>564<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Former House Speaker <a href="/wiki/Nancy_Pelosi" title="Nancy Pelosi">Nancy Pelosi</a> also disagreed with Sanders, blaming the party's loss on Biden's late exit and the lack of an open Democratic primary.<sup id="cite_ref-576" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-576"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>565<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> 
</p><p>Senator <a href="/wiki/Chris_Murphy" title="Chris Murphy">Chris Murphy</a> (D-CT) believed that the Democrats could not connect to a large amount of voters and should embrace <a href="/wiki/Populism" title="Populism">populism</a> going forward.<sup id="cite_ref-577" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-577"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>566<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-578" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-578"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>567<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Representative <a href="/wiki/Ritchie_Torres" title="Ritchie Torres">Ritchie Torres</a> (D-NY) attributed Trump's victory to public discontent over inflation and immigration; he asserted that Harris ran an effective campaign, but could not overcome a difficult electoral environment.<sup id="cite_ref-579" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-579"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>568<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:P20241113CS-0503_(cropped).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/P20241113CS-0503_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-P20241113CS-0503_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="206" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/P20241113CS-0503_%28cropped%29.jpg/500px-P20241113CS-0503_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2427" data-file-height="1998"></a><figcaption>President <a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a> (right) and President-elect <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> (left) meet in the <a href="/wiki/Oval_Office" title="Oval Office">Oval Office</a> of the <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">White House</a> as part of the presidential transition.</figcaption></figure>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Financial">Financial</h4></div>
<p>Wall Street's main indexes reported record highs on the day after the election, with the <a href="/wiki/Dow_Jones_Industrial_Average" title="Dow Jones Industrial Average">Dow Jones Industrial Average</a> up 3.57%, the <a href="/wiki/S%26P_500" title="S&amp;P 500">S&amp;P 500</a> up 2.53%, and <a href="/wiki/Nasdaq" title="Nasdaq">Nasdaq</a> up 2.95%.<sup id="cite_ref-rdowandstuff_580-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rdowandstuff-580"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>569<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="&quot;Stolen_election&quot;_conspiracy_theories"><span id=".22Stolen_election.22_conspiracy_theories"></span>"Stolen election" conspiracy theories</h4></div>
<p>Following Trump's victory, some Harris supporters on <a href="/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">X</a> shared <a href="/wiki/Election_denial" class="mw-redirect" title="Election denial">election denial</a> conspiracy theories, claiming that millions of ballots were "left uncounted" and there being something "not right" with the election. Such posts falsely claiming Trump "stole" the election peaked at noon the day after at 94,000 posts per hour, with many receiving amplification and gaining over a million views each. According to <a href="/wiki/Gordon_Crovitz" class="mw-redirect" title="Gordon Crovitz">Gordon Crovitz</a>, the CEO of the media rating system <a href="/wiki/NewsGuard" title="NewsGuard">NewsGuard</a>, the phrase "Trump cheated" received 92,100 mentions on the platform from midnight until the Wednesday morning after.<sup id="cite_ref-Wired_Nov7_581-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wired_Nov7-581"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>570<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Besides the claims from Harris's supporters, some Trump supporters baselessly claimed the disparity between other years, the 2020 election, and a then-incomplete 2024 voting total indicated voter fraud in the 2020 election.<sup id="cite_ref-APEDENIALNOV_582-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-APEDENIALNOV-582"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>571<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ABC_AU_fraud_claims_583-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ABC_AU_fraud_claims-583"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>572<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>One major "basis" these false claims were founded upon was a claim that Biden won 20 million more votes in his prior election bid than Harris had in hers, at the time.<sup id="cite_ref-APEDENIALNOV_582-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-APEDENIALNOV-582"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>571<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ABC_AU_fraud_claims_583-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ABC_AU_fraud_claims-583"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>572<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> American journalist and conspiracy theorist <a href="/wiki/Wayne_Madsen_(journalist)" title="Wayne Madsen (journalist)">Wayne Madsen</a> commented on <a href="/wiki/Threads_(social_network)" title="Threads (social network)">Threads</a>: "I'm beginning to believe our election was <a href="/wiki/2024_Georgian_parliamentary_election" title="2024 Georgian parliamentary election">massively hacked just like happened a few weeks ago in the Republic of Georgia</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-Czopek_2024_584-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Czopek_2024-584"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>573<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> At the time these fallacies were disseminated, votes were still being counted in many states.<sup id="cite_ref-Wired_Nov7_581-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wired_Nov7-581"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>570<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-KGW8_585-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KGW8-585"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>574<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> An estimate around the time using the Associated Press vote percentage total found that 16.2&nbsp;million votes across twenty states and D.C. had yet to be counted. Statistical analysis of voting asserted that despite continued counting, the projections were already set and new ballots would not sway the outcomes of any of the states and D.C.<sup id="cite_ref-KGW8_585-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KGW8-585"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>574<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Cybersecurity_and_Infrastructure_Security_Agency" title="Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency">Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency</a> director <a href="/wiki/Jen_Easterly" title="Jen Easterly">Jen Easterly</a> refuted the false claims, and wrote in a statement that there was "no evidence of any malicious activity that had a material impact on the security or integrity of our election infrastructure".<sup id="cite_ref-Wired_Nov7_581-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wired_Nov7-581"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>570<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Czopek_2024_584-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Czopek_2024-584"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>573<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Another false claim alleges Musk used the satellite internet constellation <a href="/wiki/Starlink" title="Starlink">Starlink</a> to change the results of the election. <a href="/wiki/Chief_technology_officer" title="Chief technology officer">Chief technology officer</a> Chip Trowbridge of voting system manufacturer Clear Ballot dismissed the claim and added no machine used to scan voting ballots have any network connection whatsoever.<sup id="cite_ref-Whisnant_2024_586-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Whisnant_2024-586"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>575<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Text_message_harassment">Text message harassment</h4></div>
<p>Numerous Black Americans across multiple states reported receiving <a href="/wiki/Plantation_group_text_messages" title="Plantation group text messages">threatening, racist text messages</a> the day after the election. Some of the texts referenced the incoming Trump administration, but the sender<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (April 2025)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> remained unknown as of November 10, 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-587" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-587"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>576<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Days later, several Hispanic and LGBTQIA students also reported receiving similar harassment through text messages and emails.<sup id="cite_ref-588" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-588"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>577<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Media_analysis">Media analysis</h2></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Harris's_loss"><span id="Harris.27s_loss"></span>Harris's loss</h3></div>
<p>Harris's loss to Trump received substantial media analysis. Proposed explanations for the outcome of the race included inflation, the <a href="/wiki/Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_border_crisis" title="MexicoUnited States border crisis">immigration crisis</a>, a global incumbency backlash, Biden's late exit from the race, and the lack of an open Democratic primary process. Democrats and others argued about what went wrong and how the party should move forward.<sup id="cite_ref-589" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-589"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>578<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-590" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-590"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>579<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Electoral_environment">Electoral environment</h4></div>
<p>According to <a href="/wiki/Gallup,_Inc." title="Gallup, Inc.">Gallup</a>, most factors with respect to the electoral environment favored Republicans and Trump. These included low confidence in the economy, Republicans outnumbering Democrats in party affiliation (48-45%), low national satisfaction, Republicans being favored to address the economy and immigration, and Biden's low job approval rating. Harris was viewed more favorably on character and had an advantage on some issues.<sup id="cite_ref-591" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-591"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>580<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> No incumbent party has won when a president had below a 45% approval rating, either losing reelection (<a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Carter" title="Jimmy Carter">Jimmy Carter</a> in <a href="/wiki/1980_United_States_presidential_election" title="1980 United States presidential election">1980</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">George H. W. Bush</a> in <a href="/wiki/1992_United_States_presidential_election" title="1992 United States presidential election">1992</a>, and Trump himself in <a href="/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election" title="2020 United States presidential election">2020</a>) or the incumbent party lost the White House (<a href="/wiki/Hubert_Humphrey" title="Hubert Humphrey">Hubert Humphrey</a> in <a href="/wiki/1968_United_States_presidential_election" title="1968 United States presidential election">1968</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-Why_They_Lost_592-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Why_They_Lost-592"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>581<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hard_Time_593-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hard_Time-593"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>582<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>According to exit polls, voters disapproved of Biden's performance 59-39%, and disapproved of how things were going in the United States 73-25%. Also, voters judged the economy negatively 68-32%,<sup id="cite_ref-Economy_Sucks_594-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economy_Sucks-594"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>583<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and said that inflation had caused them hardship 75-24%.<sup id="cite_ref-cnn-national-results_466-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cnn-national-results-466"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>462<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/YouGov" title="YouGov">YouGov</a> poll conducted from November 67, 2024 found that if Biden had been the Democratic nominee, Trump would have won the popular vote 49-42%.<sup id="cite_ref-595" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-595"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>584<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Nonpartisan election forecasters, including <i>The Cook Political Report</i> and <i>Sabato's Crystal Ball</i>, stated before the election that Biden would have been almost certain to lose.<sup id="cite_ref-596" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-596"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>585<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-597" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-597"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>586<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Harris did improve compared to Biden among voters making over $100,000 a year.<sup id="cite_ref-Poorer_voters_567-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Poorer_voters-567"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>556<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/NBC_News" title="NBC News">NBC News</a> found that Trump made larger gains in counties with tougher housing markets.<sup id="cite_ref-598" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-598"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>587<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Almost every incumbent party worldwide facing election in 2024 lost vote share, including in <a href="/wiki/2024_South_African_general_election" title="2024 South African general election">South Africa</a>, <a href="/wiki/2024_Indian_general_election" title="2024 Indian general election">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/2024_French_legislative_election" title="2024 French legislative election">France</a>, the <a href="/wiki/2024_United_Kingdom_general_election" title="2024 United Kingdom general election">United Kingdom</a>, and <a href="/wiki/2024_Japanese_general_election" title="2024 Japanese general election">Japan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-incumbents-defeated_599-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-incumbents-defeated-599"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>588<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-anti-incumbent-leaders-backlash_600-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-anti-incumbent-leaders-backlash-600"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>589<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Among democracies, over 80 percent saw the incumbent party lose support compared to the last election.<sup id="cite_ref-democrats-incumbent-parties_601-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-democrats-incumbent-parties-601"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>590<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This is the first time this has ever happened since 1905 (when data was first recorded) and the first time in the <a href="/wiki/History_of_democracy" title="History of democracy">history of democracy</a>, as <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal suffrage</a> began in 1894.<sup id="cite_ref-602" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-602"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>591<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-603" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-603"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>592<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>All 50 states and the District of Columbia shifted rightward compared to 2020. Trump's gains in nearly all geographic areas and among nearly every demographic group provides strong evidence of anti-incumbent backlash.<sup id="cite_ref-604" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-604"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>593<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-global-trend-incumbents_605-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-global-trend-incumbents-605"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>594<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The shifts toward Trump were much less in the swing states where both campaigns focused compared to safe states. The two states with the largest shifts toward Trump, New York and New Jersey, were both won by Harris. Harris had very little room to fall in the swing states, given that Biden had won most of them by very small margins in 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-606" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-606"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>595<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Statistician and election analyst <a href="/wiki/Nate_Silver" title="Nate Silver">Nate Silver</a> argued before the election that the national electoral environment was difficult for Democrats.<sup id="cite_ref-607" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-607"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>596<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This view was also shared by <i>The New York Times</i> political analyst <a href="/wiki/Nate_Cohn" title="Nate Cohn">Nate Cohn</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Hard_Time_593-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hard_Time-593"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>582<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> After the election, Silver felt that Harris was a <a href="/wiki/Value_over_replacement_player" title="Value over replacement player">replacement-level</a> candidate who did much better than Biden would have, but was unable to separate herself from Biden's record and was negatively perceived by swing voters due to her previous positions.<sup id="cite_ref-replacement-level_608-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-replacement-level-608"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>597<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Amy_Walter" title="Amy Walter">Amy Walter</a>, editor of the nonpartisan <i>The Cook Political Report</i>, also argued that the electoral environment was inherently difficult for Harris because the top issue for voters was inflation during the Biden-Harris administration.<sup id="cite_ref-609" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-609"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>598<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Ronald_Brownstein" class="mw-redirect" title="Ronald Brownstein">Ronald Brownstein</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Atlantic" title="The Atlantic">The Atlantic</a></i>, who spoke with members of <a href="/wiki/Kamala_Harris_2024_presidential_campaign" title="Kamala Harris 2024 presidential campaign">Harris's campaign</a>, argued that the extent of Biden's unpopularity and public discontent with the economy proved too much for Harris to overcome. Brownstein compared the election to the <a href="/wiki/1968_United_States_presidential_election" title="1968 United States presidential election">1968 presidential election</a> (when unpopular incumbent <a href="/wiki/Withdrawal_of_Lyndon_B._Johnson_from_the_1968_United_States_presidential_election" title="Withdrawal of Lyndon B. Johnson from the 1968 United States presidential election">Lyndon B. Johnson withdrew his candidacy</a> and Vice President <a href="/wiki/Hubert_Humphrey" title="Hubert Humphrey">Hubert Humphrey</a> lost to <a href="/wiki/Richard_Nixon" title="Richard Nixon">Richard Nixon</a>) and the <a href="/wiki/1980_United_States_presidential_election" title="1980 United States presidential election">1980 presidential election</a> (when incumbent <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Carter" title="Jimmy Carter">Jimmy Carter</a> lost to <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> due to <a href="/wiki/Stagflation" title="Stagflation">stagflation</a> and the <a href="/wiki/1970s_energy_crisis" title="1970s energy crisis">1970s energy crisis</a>). Members of Harris's campaign stated after the election that their internal polling never showed Harris ahead of Trump and they did not believe that Harris was the favorite to win the election.<sup id="cite_ref-Why_They_Lost_592-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Why_They_Lost-592"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>581<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/David_Plouffe" title="David Plouffe">David Plouffe</a>, a senior campaign advisor to Harris, claimed that even making the race competitive was a win for Harris's staff.<sup id="cite_ref-610" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-610"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>599<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>An analysis released by Democratic-leaning data firm <a href="/wiki/Catalist" title="Catalist">Catalist</a> in May 2025 found that Trump's victory rested on support from voters who were less engaged with politics, as well as weakened support and turnout for Harris from a range of Democratic-leaning groups. Nearly half of the 2024 electorate cast ballots in the previous four federal elections, representing an increase of 9 points from 2020 and 7 points from 2016, and Harris won under 50 percent of these voters, outperforming Biden's and <a href="/wiki/Hillary_Clinton" title="Hillary Clinton">Hillary Clinton</a>'s respective performances. In contrast, Harris won 48 percent of voters who only voted in two or fewer of the previous four federal elections, underperforming Biden and Clinton, both of whom won at least 54 percent of those voters. Harris also won less than half of voters who did not cast a vote in 2020 but did so in 2024, compared to Biden and Clinton each winning roughly 55 percent of new voters in their respective elections; Catalist considered this Democratic underperformance to be unprecedented in their history of election analysis. Jennifer Agiesta of <a href="/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a> reported that new and infrequent voters in 2024 were more likely to be from Democratic-leaning groups but also less likely to have college degrees, a trait increasingly tied to Republican support.<sup id="cite_ref-611" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-611"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>600<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-612" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-612"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>601<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Analyst_assessments">Analyst assessments</h4></div>
<figure class="mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Educational_Attainment_in_the_States_won_by_Kamala_Harris_in_2024.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Educational_Attainment_in_the_States_won_by_Kamala_Harris_in_2024.png/330px-Educational_Attainment_in_the_States_won_by_Kamala_Harris_in_2024.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="201" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Educational_Attainment_in_the_States_won_by_Kamala_Harris_in_2024.png/500px-Educational_Attainment_in_the_States_won_by_Kamala_Harris_in_2024.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Educational_Attainment_in_the_States_won_by_Kamala_Harris_in_2024.png/960px-Educational_Attainment_in_the_States_won_by_Kamala_Harris_in_2024.png 2x" data-file-width="2102" data-file-height="1406"></a><figcaption>Bar plot of the percentage of the population with a bachelor's degree in the electoral jurisdictions won by Harris in the election<sup id="cite_ref-CensusData_613-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CensusData-613"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>602<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/The_Independent" title="The Independent">The Independent</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s <a href="/wiki/Jon_Sopel" title="Jon Sopel">Jon Sopel</a> wrote that the most pressing issues that decided Harris's defeat were matters Biden had been perceived as a failure at by the American public; these included the fact that, as part of the global <a href="/wiki/2021%E2%80%932023_inflation_surge" title="20212023 inflation surge">20212023 inflation surge</a>, inflation went up by 20% and <a href="/wiki/Real_wages" title="Real wages">real wages</a> had not adjusted to match, and the state of the <a href="/wiki/Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_border" title="MexicoUnited States border">MexicoUnited States border</a>. Sopel said that by "embracing the Biden agenda, [Harris] was simply tying herself to his unpopularity".<sup id="cite_ref-independent-why-lose_614-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-independent-why-lose-614"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>603<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In a <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> piece, Henry M. J. Tonks tied the result to the party's prioritization of <a href="/wiki/Professional_class" class="mw-redirect" title="Professional class">professional class</a> workers and suburbs over working class, <a href="/wiki/Blue-collar_worker" title="Blue-collar worker">blue-collar</a> voters. He argued the shift away from working-class voters had been occurring since the late 1960s in response to the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a> and the growth of the <a href="/wiki/Tech_industry" class="mw-redirect" title="Tech industry">tech industry</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-time-alignment-history_615-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-time-alignment-history-615"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>604<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Of the electoral jurisdictions that Harris won  19 states, DC, and Nebraska's second congressional district  all except New Mexico had above-average educational attainment.<sup id="cite_ref-616" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-616"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>605<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a>'s Edward-Isaac Dovere felt that some problems, such as the problems with her staff, could have been solved, but other problems such as her ties with Biden could not have been solved. Dovere mused that had Biden stepped down earlier, the Democratic Party might have had the time to launch a proper primary campaign. He also mused that Walz was chosen because he could not "outshine" her, and that this reflected her "newfound confidence and her long-standing insecurity".<sup id="cite_ref-617" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-617"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>606<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Economic_Times" title="The Economic Times">The Economic Times</a></i> cited surveys showing "broad negative sentiment" about the economy, and Harris being "relentlessly hammered" by Trump during campaigns about this. <i>The Economic Times</i> cited <a href="/wiki/University_of_Richmond_School_of_Law" title="University of Richmond School of Law">University of Richmond School of Law</a> professor Carl Tobias's appraisal of Trump's stance on immigration winning over Harris's, and mentioned how Trump had increased his support from Hispanics, especially near the MexicanAmerican border and in areas impacted by recent immigration.<sup id="cite_ref-went_wrong_618-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-went_wrong-618"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>607<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Harris campaigning at multiple events with former Republican representative <a href="/wiki/Liz_Cheney" title="Liz Cheney">Liz Cheney</a> has been suggested as a contributing factor as to why she lost.<sup id="cite_ref-619" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-619"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>608<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-620" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-620"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>609<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-621" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-621"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>610<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><i><a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times" title="Los Angeles Times">Los Angeles Times</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s Noah Bierman felt Harris could not overcome being the "turn the page" candidate, and cited former president <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a>'s lead strategist <a href="/wiki/David_Axelrod" title="David Axelrod">David Axelrod</a>, who said: "If you're the vice president of an administration people want to fire, you're way behind the eight-ball to start." Bierman wrote that besides criminal context, Trump "never followed a script, scoffed at the rules and spoke directly to the economic and cultural anxieties of the country".<sup id="cite_ref-latimes-what-went-wrong_622-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-latimes-what-went-wrong-622"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>611<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>, Timothy Shenk argued that Democrats failed to articulate a vision for the future other than being against Trump and did not lean into a message of <a href="/wiki/Economic_populism" class="mw-redirect" title="Economic populism">economic populism</a> that polled best with swing voters but also that the election looked more like a rejection of Biden than the embrace of Trump.<sup id="cite_ref-nyt-democrats-resistance-trump_623-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-democrats-resistance-trump-623"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>612<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In another <i>The New York Times</i> article, <a href="/wiki/Nate_Cohn" title="Nate Cohn">Nate Cohn</a> analyzed exit polls showing Trump's gains among Non-White and young voters, suggesting Trump's populist message resonated with many voters previously considered part of the Democratic Party's base.<sup id="cite_ref-Lost_Their_624-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lost_Their-624"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>613<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jen_Psaki" title="Jen Psaki">Jen Psaki</a>, who served as Biden's first <a href="/wiki/White_House_Press_Secretary" title="White House Press Secretary">press secretary</a>, suggested that Harris focusing on <a href="/wiki/Never_Trump_movement" title="Never Trump movement">Anti-Trump Republicans</a> was not a winning strategy.<sup id="cite_ref-625" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-625"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>614<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Charlie Cook, founder of the nonpartisan <i>The Cook Political Report</i>, said that swing voters broke in favor of Trump due to anger over inflation associated with the Biden-Harris administration, causing Trump to sweep the swing states. However, Democrats did better in down-ballot races, meaning Trump did not have a strong <a href="/wiki/Coattail_effect" title="Coattail effect">coattail effect</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-626" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-626"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>615<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Atlantic" title="The Atlantic">The Atlantic</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Brownstein" class="mw-redirect" title="Ronald Brownstein">Ronald Brownstein</a> argued that the Democratic Party's success in the <a href="/wiki/2022_United_States_elections" title="2022 United States elections">2022 midterm elections</a>, when Trump was not on the ballot, had led them to underestimate Trump's support. Democrats also performed better than Harris in down-ballot races, suggesting voters likely assigned their blame over the economy on the Biden-Harris administration rather than the Democratic Party at-large.<sup id="cite_ref-627" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-627"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>616<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a>'s Courtney Subramanian said Harris "couldn't shake the anti-Biden sentiment that permeated much of the electorate", that she "failed to deliver a convincing argument about why she should lead the country", did not state a strategy to combat economic frustrations, and failed to address widespread concerns over immigration.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc-why_628-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-why-628"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>617<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Vox_(website)" title="Vox (website)">Vox</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s Nicole Narea highlighted inflation outpacing wages in certain industries, rising <a href="/wiki/Unemployment_in_the_United_States" title="Unemployment in the United States">unemployment</a>, and rising <a href="/wiki/Consumer_debt" title="Consumer debt">consumer debt</a> and falling savings as key economic indicators that Democrats "may have missed".<sup id="cite_ref-629" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-629"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>618<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In another <i>Vox</i> article, Andrew Prokop argued Harris suffered from a worldwide backlash to incumbents over inflation, as well as her struggles unifying the party over Gaza, failing to be a change candidate, and her difficulty in defending or abandoning positions she took during her <a href="/wiki/Kamala_Harris_2020_presidential_campaign" title="Kamala Harris 2020 presidential campaign">2020 presidential run</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-630" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-630"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>619<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Trump's_victory"><span id="Trump.27s_victory"></span>Trump's victory</h3></div>
<p>Although many conventional metrics indicated that the American economy had recovered from the COVID-19 pandemic (wages increased and inflation was in check), and although migrant crossings at the U.S.-Mexico border had declined significantly since earlier in the Biden administration, an AP article stated that Trump was able to convince voters to support him in 2024 by promising to fix the economy and block the flow of immigrants at the border.<sup id="cite_ref-631" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-631"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>620<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> According to exit polls, voters whose top issues were the economy and immigration largely voted for Trump.<sup id="cite_ref-Economy_Sucks_594-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economy_Sucks-594"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>583<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><i>Time</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s Eric Cortellessa wrote that the thesis of Trump's campaign boiled down to this simple slogan: "Max out the men and hold the women". To accomplish this goal, Trump "relentlessly" emphasized the economy and immigration. Cortellessa also mentioned Trump's minimization of his numerous controversies and his success in having his criminal trials postponed until after the election. He said that Trump's "advanced age and increasingly incoherent trail rhetoric" were taken in stride by voters, and that "much of the country read Trump's legal woes as part of a larger corrupt conspiracy to deny him, and them, power".<sup id="cite_ref-632" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-632"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>621<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/NPR" title="NPR">NPR</a> wrote that "Americans have continued to chafe at higher than pre-pandemic prices and the lack of affordable housing", and that much of the voter placed the blame "squarely" on the Biden administration. NPR said demographics played an important role in the election, with <a href="/wiki/White_Americans" title="White Americans">White</a> voters going up as a share of the electorate from 67% to 71% and Trump winning 46% of <a href="/wiki/Hispanic_and_Latino_Americans" title="Hispanic and Latino Americans">Latinos</a>. NPR also noted that polls underestimated Trump's level of support in battleground states and across the nation.<sup id="cite_ref-633" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-633"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>622<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><i>The New York Times</i> asserted that "[Trump] made one essential bet: that his grievances would become the <a href="/wiki/Grievance" title="Grievance">grievances</a> of the MAGA movement, and then the G.O.P., and then more than half the country. It paid off." <i>The Times</i> added that Trump's several setbacks actually benefited <a href="/wiki/Public_image_of_Donald_Trump" title="Public image of Donald Trump">his public image</a> and approval, as "<a href="/wiki/Mug_shot_of_Donald_Trump" title="Mug shot of Donald Trump">his mug shot</a> became a best-selling shirt. His criminal conviction inspired $100&nbsp;million in donations in one day. The <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_raised-fist_photographs" title="Donald Trump raised-fist photographs">images of him bleeding</a> after a failed assassination attempt became the symbol of what supporters saw as a campaign of destiny."<sup id="cite_ref-nyt20241107_432-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt20241107-432"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>431<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">NBC</a> mentioned a Democratic strategist's contention that male voters' belief that they were "being left behind, that society doesn't have a place for them" was a major factor in men's support for Trump. The network said that Trump's approval ratings among non-college-educated and middle-income voters, especially among Latinos and young men, showed that he had made strides in his promise to assemble a multiracial, working-class coalition.<sup id="cite_ref-NBC_how_it_went_down_634-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NBC_how_it_went_down-634"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>623<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump increased his support from Hispanics from 2020 to 2024, especially near the MexicanAmerican border and in areas impacted by recent immigration.<sup id="cite_ref-went_wrong_618-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-went_wrong-618"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>607<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Several observers pointed to shifting habits in how Americans consume media and a growing lack of trust in mainstream news outlets.<sup id="cite_ref-635" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-635"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>624<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-636" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-636"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>625<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Trump embraced alternative media through podcasts and online streamers such as <a href="/wiki/Joe_Rogan" title="Joe Rogan">Joe Rogan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adin_Ross" title="Adin Ross">Adin Ross</a>, <a href="/wiki/Theo_Von" title="Theo Von">Theo Von</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Nelk_Boys" class="mw-redirect" title="Nelk Boys">Nelk Boys</a>. <i>The New York Times</i> reported that such avenues "presented a way for Mr. Trump to sidestep more confrontational interviews with professional journalists, where he might face tough questions, fact-checks and detailed policy debates. The influencers he met with rarely challenged Mr. Trump, and often lavished him with praise."<sup id="cite_ref-637" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-637"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>626<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Observers also highlighted Trump's courting of the "<a href="/wiki/Manosphere" title="Manosphere">manosphere</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-638" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-638"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>627<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> a collection of what <i>The Guardian</i> described as "male <a href="/wiki/Podcast" title="Podcast">podcasters</a>, influencers and public figures" that "marketed themselves as <a href="/wiki/Freethought" title="Freethought">free-thinking</a> pundits who evaded the bounds of political classification".<sup id="cite_ref-639" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-639"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>628<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Post-election research showed that nearly 40% of young voters got their news from social media influencers, and that a majority of those influencers leaned right.<sup id="cite_ref-640" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-640"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>629<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><i>The New York Times</i> reported that Trump's super PAC had joined a long list of presidential campaigns that made a "technological leap or innovation" while targeting key voters. <i>The Times</i> highlighted the use of <a href="/wiki/Targeted_advertising" title="Targeted advertising">targeted advertising</a> of individual undecided voters on <a href="/wiki/Video_on_demand" title="Video on demand">streaming video platforms</a> that allowed the PAC to save money, while Harris largely targeted ads on streaming platforms by geography. It reported the Trump team's findings that the undecided electorate was younger, black, and Hispanic, and that such voters largely used streaming media over traditional broadcast television.<sup id="cite_ref-641" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-641"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>630<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Journalist <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_Spiers" title="Elizabeth Spiers">Elizabeth Spiers</a> argued that Trump's strong support among young white men could be attributed to his campaign "channeling what psychologists call '<a href="/wiki/Hegemonic_masculinity" title="Hegemonic masculinity">hegemonic masculinity</a><span style="padding-right:.15em;">'</span>".  Spiers added that "For men unhappy with their status, this view offers a group of people to blame, which feels more tangible than blaming systemic problems like rising economic inequality and the difficulty of adapting to technological and cultural changes."<sup id="cite_ref-642" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-642"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>631<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Notes">Notes</h2></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1239543626">.mw-parser-output .reflist{margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}@media screen{.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%}}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha"><div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-12">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">While Trump's proposed deportation program primarily targeted illegal immigrants, he also pledged to displace legal immigrants.<sup id="cite_ref-Oliphant_10042024_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oliphant_10042024-11"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-454"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-454">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">States rated safe by all other forecasts but <i><a href="/wiki/FiveThirtyEight" title="FiveThirtyEight">FiveThirtyEight</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a></i> are omitted. The <i>FiveThirtyEight</i> forecast and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a></i> each rate only a handful of states as "safe".<sup id="cite_ref-FiveThirtyEight-2024_452-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FiveThirtyEight-2024-452"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>451<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_Economist-2024_453-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Economist-2024-453"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>452<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-ME/NE-464"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-ME/NE_464-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ME/NE_464-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ME/NE_464-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ME/NE_464-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Unlike the other 48 states and Washington, D.C., which award all of their electors to the candidate who receives the most votes in that state, Maine and Nebraska award two electors to the winner of the statewide vote and one each to the candidate who receives the most votes in each congressional district.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Districts-465"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Districts_465-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Districts_465-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Districts_465-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">The boundaries of Maine and Nebraska's congressional districts have since changed because of redistricting.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-491"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-491">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Percentage point difference in margin from the <a href="/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election" title="2020 United States presidential election">2020 election</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-542"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-542">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The District of Columbia is not a state or a county, but a district with three electoral votes.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-543"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-543">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Petersburg, Virginia is not a state or a county, but an independent city.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-544"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-544">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Baltimore, Maryland is not a state or a county, but an independent city.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-545"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-545">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In <a href="/wiki/Maine" title="Maine">Maine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nebraska" title="Nebraska">Nebraska</a>, electoral votes are allocated by congressional district, with two votes going to the state at-large. The insets in those states illustrate this distribution and have no geographical significance.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-equivalent-546"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-equivalent_546-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-equivalent_546-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-equivalent_546-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">County equivalents are used in <a href="/wiki/Alaska" title="Alaska">Alaska</a> and <a href="/wiki/Louisiana" title="Louisiana">Louisiana</a>. The <a href="/wiki/District_of_Columbia" class="mw-redirect" title="District of Columbia">District of Columbia</a> has no primary subdivisions.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-548"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-548">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The term "trend" refers to the swing in county vote margins relative to the national swing in the popular vote.</span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<li id="cite_note-173"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-173">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite id="CITEREFPipia2024" class="citation web cs1">Pipia, Lindsey (May 15, 2024). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2024-election/american-samoa-primary-victor-jason-palmer-bows-presidential-race-rcna152509">"American Samoa primary victor Jason Palmer bows out of the presidential race"</a>. <li id="cite_note-244"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-244">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite id="CITEREFMcCammon2024" class="citation news cs1">McCammon, Sarah (September 10, 2024). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.npr.org/2024/09/10/nx-s1-5107942/abortion-roe-wade-ivf-donald-trump-kamala-harris-debate-2024">"Trump repeats the false claim that Democrats support abortion 'after birth' in debate"</a>. <a href="/wiki/NPR" title="NPR">NPR</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-284"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-284">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.iea.org/topics/global-energy-crisis">"IEA Global Energy Crisis"</a>. <li id="cite_note-394"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-394">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.pbs.org/newshour/politics/biden-emphasizes-that-majority-of-ukraine-aid-package-would-be-spend-in-u-s">"Biden emphasizes that majority of Ukraine aid package would be spent in U.S."</a> <i><a href="/wiki/PBS_News" class="mw-redirect" title="PBS News">PBS News</a></i>. April 2025</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Category:Articles_containing_video_clips" title="Category:Articles containing video clips">Articles containing video clips</a></li></ul></div></div>
				</div>
			</main>
			
		</div>
